{"uri": "8114144196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:36:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:36:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:34:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/new-snp-leader-john-swinney-on-course-to-be-scotlands-first-minister-5644537", "title": "New SNP Leader John Swinney on Course to be Scotland's First Minister", "body": "John Swinney -- who led the SNP from 2000 to 2004 -- has been elected unopposed as the party's new leader and is set to become Scotland's first minister.\n\nJohn Swinney has become the new leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) and is set to become Scotland's First Minister, succeeding Humza Yousaf who resigned after falling out with the Greens.\n\nIn his first speech as leader Mr. Swinney, condemned the \"polarisation\" of Scottish politics and said he would listen to factions within the party and seek \"compromises\" with other parties.\n\nMr. Swinney, 60, led the party between 2000 and 2004 but the SNP's electoral success came under his successors Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nMs. Sturgeon resigned last year and was replaced by Mr. Yousaf but he was forced out last week after he terminated the Bute House power-sharing agreement with the Greens after disagreeing on climate policy and gender identity issues.\n\nAfter Scotland's finance secretary, Kate Forbes, decided against challenging Mr Swinney, he was elected as leader of the SNP unopposed.\n\nBecause the party dominates the Scottish Parliament he is all set to become the country's next first minister.\n\nIt is not clear if he was indicating plans to resume or renegotiate the Bute House agreement with the Greens.\n\nMr. Swinney said: \"If elected first minister, my focus will be the economy, jobs, the cost of living. It will be the NHS, our schools and our public services. It will be addressing the climate crisis.\"\n\nHe urged the SNP not to, \"let our disagreements dominate\" and told the audience, \"Join me as we open a new chapter. That's my job, that's our job, and I plan to get the job done.\"\n\nMr. Swinney accepted there would be \"controversy\" in the fact that he had been elected unopposed but he said it was perhaps a sign of the SNP, \"coming back together again.\"\n\nHe said, \"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\n\"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession -- the one issue they agree on -- and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy,\" he added.\n\nEarlier he posted a message on social media platform X saying: \"I am deeply honoured to have been elected as leader of the SNP. I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country.\"\n\nLater this week Mr. Swinney will now face a vote at Holyrood and if he wins he would be confirmed as Scotland's seventh first minister.\n\nThe first three -- Donald Dewar, Henry McLeish and Jack McConnell -- represented the Labour Party and the other four -- Mr. Salmond, Ms. Sturgeon, Mr. Yousaf and potentially Mr. Swinney -- were from the SNP.\n\nMr. Yousaf stepped down as SNP leader and Scotland's First Minister last week after pulling out of the Bute House agreement and then facing two votes of no confidence from both Labour and the Tories.\n\nAt the start of his speech on Monday, Mr. Swinney praised Mr. Yousaf' and said, \"In particular, his moral leadership on the issue of Gaza has been a light in these very dark times.\"\n\nMr. Yousaf in turn congratulated Mr. Swinney.\n\nWriting on X, Mr. Yousaf went on to say: \"John's central message has been one of unity. As a party, we must heed his call, whatever has happened in the past should remain there. Let's get behind John and his team so they can deliver for Scotland.\"\n\nBut Labour's leader in Scotland, Anas Sarwar, said: \"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same. John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\"\n\n\"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure,\" he added.\n\nThe next elections to the Scottish parliament are not until 2026.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112870251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:39:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:39:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:38:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/swinney-become-snp-leader-challenger-222558183.html", "title": "Swinney to become SNP leader after challenger drops out", "body": "SNP leadership front-runner John Swinney is expected to succeed Humza Yousaf unopposed after a potential challenger withdrew his bid at the 11th hour.\n\nEarlier on Sunday it emerged that veteran SNP activist Graeme McCormick, who has been openly critical of the Scottish government, had secured a nomination.\n\nHowever he announced later that although he had met the threshold of support needed to secure a nomination, he had decided not to proceed and would back Mr Swinney instead.\n\nThis came after a \"lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Mr Swinney in which Mr McCormick said they had agreed the challenges which the SNP, the government and the people face.\n\nThis means Mr Swinney is expected to be elected leader of the SNP after nominations close at midday on Monday.\n\nMr Yousaf resigned after just over a year in the role following the fallout from the decision to terminate a power-sharing deal with the Scottish Greens.\n\nLater that week Mr Swinney announced that he was putting his name forward as he gave a speech at an event in Edinburgh last week.\n\nMr Swinney, 60, previously led the SNP between 2000 and 2004 and said he would not be \"interim leader\" or a \"caretaker,\" adding he intended to see out a full term.\n\nOn Sunday he suggested that rebuilding the SNP could be delayed if another candidate were to enter the leadership race - though said he would engage with internal party democracy.\n\nHis preference, he said, was to \"get on with things\" as the party had not been as cohesive as it should have been in recent years.\n\nLeadership candidates are required to get 100 nominations from at least 20 local SNP branches before standing in the race.\n\nMr McCormick is a retired lawyer and stood against Mike Russell to become party president in 2023, losing by 599 votes to 79.\n\nHe previously argued for abolishing tax and replacing it with an annual rent on land, and that the route to Scottish independence lay through international treaties, with Scotland dissolving the union immediately if the SNP returned the most MPs in Scotland at a general election.\n\nIn a speech at the party conference in October last year, he described the SNP government as being like \"flatulence in a trance.\"\n\nLate on Sunday, Mr McCormick released a statement saying he and Mr Swinney had \"explored new thinking on a range of issues\" that would \"inspire activists\" within the SNP and in the wider independence movement.\n\nConfirming he was backing Mr Swinney, he said: \"This is a fresh start for our members and our politicians, and I'm sure that John's determination to deliver Independence will be rewarded at the forthcoming general election.\"\n\nEarlier this week former SNP leadership candidate Kate Forbes confirmed she was not standing and backed Mr Swinney, having been promised a \"significant\" cabinet role if he becomes first minister.\n\nIf no other candidate meets the nomination deadline, Mr Swinney would be free to seek parliamentary approval to become first minister.\n\nMr Yousaf has decided to stay on in the role until a replacement is selected.\n\nOnce his resignation has been accepted by the King, parliament has 28 days to select a replacement.\n\nThere will then be a vote in the chamber to decide the new first minister, which is passed by a simple majority.\n\nThe SNP has 63 seats in the parliament, which means it does not have a majority, but the vote is likely to pass regardless.\n\nThe parliament's presiding officer then recommends to the King that the winner be appointed as the new first minister.\n\nA swearing in ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh could take place as early as Wednesday.\n\nAt that point, Mr Swinney would officially become first minister.\n\nMr Yousaf announced his intention to step down from the role last Monday.\n\nHe had ended the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens, leaving him short of support for the minority SNP government at Holyrood.\n\nHe would have faced two votes of no confidence in his leadership last week had he not stood down.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives dropped their motion after his departure was confirmed, while Scottish Labour's - which was a vote of confidence in the entire government - was defeated with backing from the Greens.\n\nHis resignation came 13 months after defeating Ms Forbes and Ash Regan, who has since defected to the Alba Party, in the race to replace Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nHe became the first ethnic minority leader of a devolved government in the UK and the first Muslim to lead a major UK party.\n\nIn his resignation speech, he said he had \"clearly underestimated\" the hurt he had caused the Greens by ending the agreement and said his replacement would be tasked with \"repairing our relationship across the political divide\".", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113714769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:45:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:45:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:44:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-wins-snp-leadership-113343348.html", "title": "John Swinney wins SNP leadership unopposed", "body": "John Swinney has moved a step closer to becoming Scotland's seventh first minister after being confirmed as SNP leader.\n\nA contest was avoided after a veteran SNP activist withdrew a rival bid following talks with Mr Swinney.\n\nThe former deputy first minister is expected to be nominated by MSPs as first minister as early as Tuesday.\n\nCurrent first minister Humza Yousaf - who announced his resignation last week - said he would formally quit once a new SNP leader was confirmed.\n\nMr Swinney, who led the SNP between 2000 and 2004, will speak at an event in Glasgow later.\n\nIn a post on X, formerly Twitter, he said he was \"deeply honoured\" to become SNP leader for the second time.\n\n\"I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country,\" he added.\n\nIt came after SNP activist, Graeme McCormick, announced at the weekend that he had enough nominations to challenge for the leadership.\n\nBut he pulled out of the contest following a \"lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Mr Swinney.\n\nSNP national secretary Lorna Finn confirmed in a statement that Mr Swinney, 60, had been confirmed as the new SNP leader.\n\nLast week potential leadership rival Kate Forbes - who served as finance secretary under Nicola Sturgeon - confirmed she would not stand.\n\nShe backed Mr Swinney after he promised her a \"significant\" role in his government.\n\nAt his campaign launch event last week, Mr Swinney said he would not be \"interim leader\" or a \"caretaker,\" adding he intended to see out a full term.\n\nAfter Humza Yousaf's resignation as first minister is accepted by the King, parliament has 28 days to nominate a replacement.\n\nWhen Mr Yousaf was nominated last year, Tory leader Douglas Ross, Labour leader Anas Sarwar and Lib Dem leader Alex Cole-Hamilton unsuccessfully ran against him.\n\nIf others decide to stand this time, a Mr Swinney would need a simple majority of votes to win - meaning more than all other candidates combined.\n\nIf there is more than one candidate, anyone who secures more than half the votes would win.\n\nIf no-one reaches this threshold, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated. This process is repeated until there are only two candidates left.\n\nAt this point, Mr Swinney only has to win more votes than his last opponent.\n\nThe SNP has 63 seats in the parliament - which is short of a majority. However, Mr Swinney is still expected to win the nomination.\n\nHolyrood's presiding officer recommends to the King that the winner is appointed as first minister.\n\nA swearing-in ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh could take place as early as Wednesday.\n\nIn response the SNP leadership confirmation, Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said: \"As the main opposition party, we will hold John Swinney to account when he lets the Scottish people down - just as we've done with Humza Yousaf.\"\n\nPatrick Harvie, co-leader of the Scottish Greens, said: \"Mr Swinney knows that if he is to have our support then it must be on the basis of progressive policies that help us to tackle the climate crisis and build a fairer and more equal future.\"\n\nEarlier, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar posted on X: \"The return of John Swinney is about putting the interests of the SNP before Scotland - only Scottish Labour can deliver the change Scotland needs.\"\n\nMr Yousaf's premiership imploded last week after he ripped up the government's power-sharing Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens.\n\nThat left the SNP administration with a minority in parliament.\n\nFacing motions of no confidence in him and his government, Mr Yousaf confirmed he was standing down last Monday.\n\nIn his resignation speech, he said he had \"clearly underestimated\" the hurt he had caused the "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2024/05/05/snp-leadership-challenger-pulls-out-of-race/", "title": "SNP leadership challenger pulls out of race to succeed Humza Yousaf", "body": "John Swinney is to become the new SNP leader on Monday after he persuaded an activist who threatened to derail his coronation to abandon his leadership bid.\n\nGraeme McCormick, a long-standing SNP member, had threatened to plunge the SNP into a costly and divisive leadership contest after he claimed he had secured enough support to force a leadership election.\n\nHowever, he revealed on Sunday night that he had held \"lengthy and fruitful talks\" with Mr Swinney and had decided to support his candidacy instead.\n\nIt means Mr Swinney is expected to be the only candidate for SNP leader when nominations close at midday on Monday, and is set to become the new first minister on Tuesday.\n\nWhile Mr Swinney would have been certain to win any leadership election, a contest would have prolonged Humza Yousaf's disastrous tenure until the end of the month and cost the cast-strapped SNP tens of thousands of pounds in an election year.\n\nMr McCormick, who was seen collecting nominations at an independence march in Glasgow on Saturday, said he had met the threshold to stand in the contest.\n\nUnder SNP rules, only 100 nominations are needed from 20 separate branches to make it onto the ballot.\n\nSenior SNP sources were nervous on Sunday that Mr McCormick would ruin the party's hopes to quickly move on from Mr Yousaf.\n\nHowever, he agreed to stand down following discussions with Mr Swinney, after apparently being convinced by Nicola Sturgeon's former deputy that he would push strongly for independence.\n\n\"I'd also like to put on record my thanks to John Swinney MSP with whom I had a lengthy and fruitful conversation,\" he added.\n\n\"John and I agreed the challenges which the SNP, our Government and our people face, and explored new thinking on a range of issues which I am confident, as they are advanced, will inspire activists both within the SNP and wider independence movement in the following weeks and months.\n\n\"This is a fresh start for our members and our politicians, and I'm sure that John's determination to deliver independence will be rewarded at the forthcoming general election.\n\n\"I have therefore concluded that I shall not proceed with my nomination for party leader but instead support John Swinney's nomination for party leader and first minister of Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney and his allies believed they had all but secured the SNP leadership when Kate Forbes, his only viable challenger, announced she would not be standing on Thursday, hours after he promised her a top government job at his campaign launch.\n\nMs Forbes also decided not to run after one-on-one talks with Mr Swinney, who has received a string of high-profile endorsements from senior party figures.\n\nHowever, Mr McCormick, a retired lawyer who has regularly criticised SNP strategy, indicated on Saturday as he attempted to find supporters at an independence march in Glasgow, that he believed he would make the ballot.\n\nOn Sunday, Mr Swinney issued a thinly-veiled public plea for Mr McCormick to stand down, a call echoed by other senior party figures.\n\nGavin Newlands, an SNP MP, branded Mr McCormick's leadership bid a \"self-indulgent waste of time which is being egged-on by folk from other parties and seized on by the media with great glee.\"\n\nPete Wishart, the SNP's longest serving MP, warned party members that unionists, members of Alex's Salmond's Alba Party and the media were \"cheering on\" a leadership contest.\n\nThe internal election could have embarrassed the SNP, as Mr McCormick holds radical positions and would temporarily have been handed a national platform.\n\nAt last year's SNP conference he branded the party's independence police \"flatulence in a trance\" and he has argued devolved taxation powers could be used to pay for universal free energy for Scots.\n\nAt an SNP independence convention last summer, he claimed that should Scots back the party manifesto at an election, its MPs should \"walk out of Westminster, declare the dissolution of the Union and set up a provisional government in Edinburgh\".\n\nMr Swinney had earlier told Sky News: \"I think the SNP has got a chance to start rebuilding from the difficult period that we have had.\n\n\"Bluntly, I'd just like to get on with that as quickly as I possibly can, because every day that we spend in an internal contest, which I think we all probably know the outcome of, we delay the ability for the SNP to start its rebuilding.\"", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Advertisement\n\nAn SNP 'lifer' - he joined the party at the age of 15 - Mr Swinney was a management consultant and life assurance industry executive before becoming MP for Tayside North in 1997.\n\nTwo years later, he was among the first intake of MSPs at Holyrood.\n\nAn early reputation for competence was shattered when Mr Swinney succeeded Alex Salmond as party leader in 2000.\n\nFor four years, he was undermined by rivals within the SNP and, unable to stamp his authority on the party, Mr Swinney suffered a series of bruising election results.\n\nWhen the SNP fared poorly in the 2004 Euro elections, a visit from the men in grey kilts brought his leadership to an end.\n\nJohn Swinney speaks as he launches his SNP leadership bid on May 02, 2024 in Edinburgh\n\nFearful the subsequent leadership contest might be won by someone from the SNP's radical wing, Mr Salmond returned as leader, going on to become Scotland's first nationalist First Minister in 2007.\n\nMr Swinney's authority across the party grew during the SNP's time in power.\n\nHe was a member of the tiny clique - including Mr Salmond and his deputy, Nicola Sturgeon - that ran the SNP with an iron fist.\n\nAnnouncing his candidacy to replace Mr Yousaf, who resigned in advance of a confidence vote he hadn't the numbers to win, Mr Swinney said he had come forward because of the need for change.\n\nJohn Swinney is crowned as SNP leader - and is set to become Scotland's new First Minister - after party dodges divisive leadership contest in wake of Humza Yousaf's meltdown Advertisement\n\nHis party had to change and if it didn't, there would be tougher times to come.\n\nScottish voters may be sceptical about Mr Swinney's ability to change the direction in which his party has been travelling.\n\nWhen Ms Sturgeon succeeded Mr Salmond as First Minister after defeat for the nationalists in the 2014 independence referendum, she appointed Mr Swinney her deputy.\n\nFor the next nine years, the pair were politically inseparable as the SNP pursued a raft of policies that were out of kilter with the priorities of voters.\n\nMr Swinney was right by Ms Sturgeon's side as she fomented deeper division with endless promises of a second referendum she had no power to deliver.\n\nAnd he was one of the key architects of the Bute House Agreement that brought the Scottish Greens into power and saw them pressure SNP ministers to push ahead with a law that gave trans people the right to self-identify.\n\nAs it came into conflict with the UK-wide Equality Act, Scottish Secretary Alister Jack was compelled to block it, a move that proved to be the beginning of the end for Ms Sturgeon.\n\nMr Swinney stepped down as Deputy First Minister when Ms Sturgeon resigned last year.\n\nSNP members now see John Swinney as their saviour but the harsh reality is that he was right behind every government misstep that helped bring his party to its knees.\n\nHe is the very his confirmation as the SNP's new leader, Mr Swinney is now likely to become Scotland's next first minister - replacing Mr Yousaf - in the coming days.\n\nHe will face a vote at Holyrood later this week, where it is likely he will become the Scottish Parliament's nominated candidate to be the country's seventh first minister.\n\nParty activist Graeme McCormick yesterday said he had secured the 100 nominations from 20 SNP branches needed to run against Mr Swinney.\n\nBut he later confirmed he had backed out of a leadership challenge after 'lengthy and fruitful' conversations with Mr Swinney.\n\nMr Swinney had earlier warned that a full-blown contest could damage the party's chances of recovering from a 'difficult' period.\n\nJohn Swinney is set to be crowned the new SNP leader today when nominations in the party's contest to replace Humza Yousaf close at noon\n\nThe SNP were forced to look for a third new leader in little more than a year after Mr Yousaf, who replaced Nicola Sturgeon in March 2023, announced his resignation last Monday\n\nKeith Brown, the SNP's depute leader, this morning said the 'field is clearing' ahead of Mr Swinney's expected coronation.\n\n'It seems to be that the field is cleaning somewhat and it looks like John Swinney might be the sole nominee,' he told the BBC's Good Morning Scotland.\n\nMr Brown described Mr Swinney as the 'biggest hitter in the SNP' who would scare unionist parties 'to a great extent'.\n\nThe SNP were forced to look for a third new leader in little more than a year after Mr Yousaf, who replaced Nicola Sturgeon in March 2023, announced his resignation last Monday.\n\nIt came after the outgoing First Minister prompted a meltdown at Holyrood by terminating the SNP's power-sharing deal with the Scottish Greens.\n\nThis blew up in Mr Yousaf's face when the Greens then turned against him and vowed to vote in favour of him being ousted from Bute House.\n\nMr Yousaf subsequently quit in order to avoid the embarrassment of losing a no confidence vote.\n\nKate Forbes, the former Scottish finance secretary who came second to Mr Yousaf in last year's SNP leadership race, had been expected to run again.\n\nBut she last week confirmed she would not run against Mr Swinney, who heaped praise on her and said she would be offered a 'significant' job in his team.\n\nThe Scottish Government Cabinet will meet on Tuesday, with MSPs later given the opportunity to elect a new first minister at some point in the Holyrood schedule.\n\nMr Swinney would then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh before officially becoming first minister.\n\nThe 60-year-old served as Ms Sturgeon's deputy first minister for almost nine years.\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP was also SNP leader between 2000 and 2004, standing down after a poor showing at the European elections.\n\nWhen he decided not to stand for the leadership last year he said it was time for a new generation to {"uri": "8112872634", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:42:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/swinney-become-snp-leader-challenger-222558183.html", "title": "Swinney to become SNP leader after challenger drops out", "body": "Earlier on Sunday it emerged that veteran SNP activist Graeme McCormick, who has been openly critical of the Scottish government, had secured a nomination.\n\nHowever he announced later that although he had met the threshold of support needed to secure a nomination, he had decided not to proceed and would back Mr Swinney instead.\n\nThis came after a \"lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Mr Swinney in which Mr McCormick said they had agreed the challenges which the SNP, the government and the people face.\n\nThis means Mr Swinney is expected to be elected leader of the SNP after nominations close at midday on Monday.\n\nMr Yousaf resigned after just over a year in the role following the fallout from the decision to terminate a power-sharing deal with the Scottish Greens.\n\nLater that week Mr Swinney announced that he was putting his name forward as he gave a speech at an event in Edinburgh last week.\n\nMr Swinney, 60, previously led the SNP between 2000 and 2004 and said he would not be \"interim leader\" or a \"caretaker,\" adding he intended to see out a full term.\n\nOn Sunday he suggested that rebuilding the SNP could be delayed if another candidate were to enter the leadership race - though said he would engage with internal party democracy.\n\nHis preference, he said, was to \"get on with things\" as the party had not been as cohesive as it should have been in recent years.\n\nLeadership candidates are required to get 100 nominations from at least 20 local SNP branches before standing in the race.\n\nMr McCormick is a retired lawyer and stood against Mike Russell to become party president in 2023, losing by 599 votes to 79.\n\nHe previously argued for abolishing tax and replacing it with an annual rent on land, and that the route to Scottish independence lay through international treaties, with Scotland dissolving the union immediately if the SNP returned the most MPs in Scotland at a general election.\n\nIn a speech at the party conference in October last year, he described the SNP government as being like \"flatulence in a trance.\"\n\nLate on Sunday, Mr McCormick released a statement saying he and Mr Swinney had \"explored new thinking on a range of issues\" that would \"inspire activists\" within the SNP and in the wider independence movement.\n\nConfirming he was backing Mr Swinney, he said: \"This is a fresh start for our members and our politicians, and I'm sure that John's determination to deliver Independence will be rewarded at the forthcoming general election.\"\n\nEarlier this week former SNP leadership candidate Kate Forbes confirmed she was not standing and backed Mr Swinney, having been promised a \"significant\" cabinet role if he becomes first minister.\n\nIf no other candidate meets the nomination deadline, Mr Swinney would be free to seek parliamentary approval to become first minister.\n\nMr Yousaf has decided to stay on in the role until a replacement is selected.\n\nOnce his resignation has been accepted by the King, parliament has 28 days to select a replacement.\n\nThere will then be a vote in the chamber to decide the new first minister, which is passed by a simple majority.\n\nThe SNP has 63 seats in the parliament, which means it does not have a majority, but the vote is likely to pass regardless.\n\nThe parliament's presiding officer then recommends to the King that the winner be appointed as the new first minister.\n\nA swearing in ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh could take place as early as Wednesday.\n\nAt that point, Mr Swinney would officially become first minister.\n\nMr Yousaf announced his intention to step down from the role last Monday.\n\nHe had ended the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Greens, leaving him short of support for the minority SNP government at Holyrood.\n\nHe would have faced two votes of no confidence in his leadership last week had he not stood down.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives dropped their motion after his departure was confirmed, while Scottish Labour's - which was a vote of confidence in the entire government - was defeated with backing from the Greens.\n\nHis resignation came 13 months after defeating Ms Forbes and Ash Regan, who has since defected to the Alba Party, in the race to replace Nicola Sturgeon.\n\nHe became the first ethnic minority leader of a devolved government in the UK and the first Muslim to lead a major UK party.\n\nIn his resignation speech, he said he had \"clearly underestimated\" the hurt he had caused the Greens by ending the agreement and said his replacement would be tasked with \"repairing our relationship across the political divide\".", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8114205787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:23:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:23:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:23:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24301962.john-swinney-im-ready-lies-ahead/", "title": "John Swinney: 'I'm physically and mentally rested. I'm ready for what lies ahead'", "body": "He told The Herald: \"I was just going 100 miles an hour all the time. And when I stopped I became aware how physically and mentally exhausted I was.\n\n\"Although I have worked hard [over the last year] I've been doing different things, so today I'm now physically and mentally rested. I'm ready for what lies ahead.\n\n\"I hope I'm being clear to you today, how much of a privilege and an honour it is to be asked to be leader of my party and to hopefully be elected as First Minister of Scotland.\"\n\n\"That inspiration and opportunity will fuel me through the challenges that lie ahead,\" he added.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney confirmed as new SNP leader\n\nMr Swinney could become First Minister within days, with Humza Yousaf expected to tender his resignation to the King on Tuesday morning.\n\nThat would trigger a nomination process in Holyrood and, if the Parliamentary Bureau agrees, a vote as tomorrow afternoon.\n\nScottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar and Scottish Lib Dem Leader Alex Cole-Hamilton have all confirmed that they too will stand in the vote.\n\nAs the SNP does not have a majority, Mr Swinney will need some opposition MSPs to either back him or abstain.\n\nDuring his acceptance speech at Glasgow University's Advanced Research Centre, the former deputy first minister, who is now set to lead a minority government, said he was keen to work cross-party and \"seek to find common ground\" and \"join together in coalitions of the willing and solve the problems our country faces\".\n\nMr Swinney, who has long been one of the Holyrood debating chamber's most prolific hecklers, admitted that he had personally contributed to the polarisation in politics.\n\n\"I've obviously contributed to that. Of course, I have.\"\n\nHe said politics was \"in the worst state I've ever seen it.\"\n\n\"So I'm here to do something about that, to change that so we can have an open and honest and respectful dialogue in Scotland about what the future holds for us, what the future should be.\n\n\"And I'm very clear what I think the future should be I'm also equally clear I won't get that by shouting at people. I'll get that by persuading people.\n\n\"That's what I'm committing myself to.\"\n\nMr Swinney acknowledged there was \"controversy\" over the fact he was the only candidate for the role.\n\nInitially, it looked as if Kate Forbes could enter the contest but she withdrew last week, offering her support to Mr Swinney.\n\nOver the weekend, it looked as if he could face a grassroots challenge when Graeme McCormick, a prominent activist gathered enough nominations to enter the race.\n\nHe later pulled out after a \"fruitful and lengthy\" conversation with Mr Swinney.\n\nThe SNP leader told the audience of MPs, MSPs, councillors, activists, journalists and Scottish Government officials that this was a sign his party - which had been through a \"rough time recently\" - was \"coming back together again.\"\n\nHe went on to say that his leadership was the \"beginning of a new chapter in our party's history.\"\n\nHe pledged to create an \"inclusive and unified team\" and to enable \"open and respectful dialogue in the SNP\", and said he would ensure the SNP looks outward to the people of Scotland.\n\nREAD MORE: Swinney pays tribute to Yousaf in his first speech as new SNP leader\n\nThe presumptive first minister said his focus would be on \"the economy, jobs, the cost of living.\"\n\n\"It will be the National Health Service, our schools and our public services. It will be addressing the climate crisis,\" he added.\n\nHe said he would \"seek, with respect and courtesy, to persuade people of the case for independence\".\n\nBut in a direct message to the other Holyrood parties, he said their opposition to leaving the UK was not a reason not to work with him on other policy areas.\n\nAsked what his one big policy idea was, Mr Swinney said he was \"determined\" to \"eradicate child poverty in Scotland.\"\n\n\"I will start focusing the government on maximising what we can do within our powers to eradicate child poverty. It is a curse.\"\n\nMr Swinney categorically ruled out another Bute House Agreement type deal with the Scottish Greens and hinted that he could yet ditch some of the policies brought forward as part of the powersharing agreement.\n\nThe comment came after Patrick Harvie warned the soon-to-be leader of the Scottish Government against \"diluting\" policies including the conversion therapy ban, rent control and the decarbonisation of heating in homes.\n\n\"We'll take it on an issue-by-issue basis,\" Mr Swinney said. \"Which means that on some issues, I'm sure we will be aligned with the Scottish Green Party. But I'm sure on other issues we'll have to find support and an agreement with other political parties.\"\n\nMr Swinney refused to be drawn on tax plans but said he agreed with Kate Forbes that the government cannot \"continually\" keep on increasing taxation.\n\nHe said there were \"sensitive judgments\" to be made.\n\n\"You've got to make the right tax judgments in the right context and the right circumstances and that's what I think the Scottish Government has done.\"\n\nHe said that people \"who are on higher incomes are able to make more of a contribution to the public finance so we can lower the burden for those on lower ends of the spectrum, but that everybody benefits from the social contract that we make available to people in Scotland.\"\n\nAt the start of his speech, he paid tribute to his predecessor, insisting Humza Yousaf would \"continue to make a substantial contribution to the public life of Scotland.\"\n\nEarlier, Mr Yousaf had congratulated his successor, as he urged SNP members to \"get behind John and his team so they can deliver for Scotland\".\n\nREAD MORE: Greens warn new SNP leader against 'diluting' conversion therapy ban\n\nScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross was scathing about Mr Swinney's victory in the contest, describing him as the \"ultimate continuity candidate.\"\n\nHe said: \"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\nThe Tory added: \"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession - the one issue they agree on - and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar repeated his call for an election: \"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\n\n\"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure.\"\n\nScottish Liberal Democrat leader Alex Cole-Hamilton agreed. He said: \"As his party's leader and a former wingman to both Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, John Swinney is now answerable for the SNP's appalling neglect of public services over the past 17 years.\n\n\"He should immediately announce a plan for cutting NHS waiting lists and stopping sewage flowing into our rivers and if he can't do that he should announce an election.\"", "source": the new SNP leader after the party confirmed he was the only candidate for the role.\n\nThe party grandee, who had an unhappy previous stint as leader which ended 20 years ago, is expected to be voted in as Scotland's seventh first minister at Holyrood on Tuesday.\n\nThe SNP confirmed on Monday that Mr Swinney was the only candidate to reach the required level of support, which is 100 nominees from party members from at least 20 different branches.\n\nMr Swinney, who was Nicola Sturgeon's long-serving deputy, last week persuaded Kate Forbes, seen as his only viable contender after he decided to run, to support him after promising her a significant role in his government.\n\nMr Swinney said on X, formerly Twitter:\n\nGraeme McCormick, a party activist, had threatened to derail Mr Swinney's coronation but he was also convinced by Mr Swinney to stand down, following talks between the pair on Sunday.\n\nUnionist parties at Holyrood have accused the SNP of mounting a \"stich-up\" to install Mr Swinney without a contest.\n\nEarly Holyrood election ruled out\n\nHe will be the third SNP first minister since Nicola Sturgeon won the 2021 Holyrood election.\n\nDespite the SNP demanding a UK general election after Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak were installed as prime ministers by the Tories, Mr Swinney has ruled out an early Holyrood election.\n\nHe is expected to hand Ms Forbes, who is on the right of the SNP, a prominent role in his government as part of a bid to unify his fractious party.\n\nKeith Brown, the SNP's deputy leader, claimed on Monday that Mr Swinney was \"the biggest hitter in the SNP\" and suggested unionist parties may come to regret toppling the unpopular Humza Yousaf.\n\nMr Yousaf was forced to resign as SNP leader and First Minister after his attempt to end his party's power-sharing pact with the Scottish Greens spectacularly backfired.\n\nThe smaller pro-independence party had planned to vote with unionist parties in a vote of no confidence against Mr Yousaf, leading to him standing down after only 13 months.\n\n\"I understand over the course of the weekend, we've people out canvassing and they've reported already an increase in positive turnout coming back from those canvassing sessions,\" Mr Brown claimed.\n\n\"So there's been an immediate lift from the discussions which John Swinney has had first of all with Kate Forbes and, it now appears, with Graeme McCormick.\"\n\nSwinney controversies\n\nHowever, opponents claim Mr Swinney is tainted by his close association with Ms Sturgeon, who has described him as \"the best friend I could have wished for\".\n\nHe has also been associated with a number of controversies during his long period at the top of the SNP.\n\nIn the last parliament, he narrowly survived two confidence votes over botching exam results during the pandemic as Education Secretary and for refusing to release legal advice about the Alex Salmond affair.\n\nMr Swinney has also previously attempted to downplay questions over party finances. Police later launched an investigation which has seen Ms Sturgeon, who denies wrongdoing, arrested and released without charge.\n\nShe remains under investigation, along with Colin Beattle, the former party treasurer, who was also arrested last year and released without charge.\n\nMs Sturgeon's husband, Peter Murrell, the former SNP chief executive, was last month charged with embezzlement of funds from the party.\n\nMr Swinney is likely to become Scotland's next first minister, the third in just over a year, as early as Tuesday.\n\nThe Scottish Government Cabinet will also meet on Tuesday, with MSPs later given the opportunity to elect a new first minister at some point in the Holyrood schedule.\n\nMr Swinney would then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh {"uri": "8114043306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:23:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:23:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:22:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/05/06/john-swinney-promises-new-chapter-for-the-snp-and-scotland/", "title": "John Swinney promises 'new chapter' for the SNP and Scotland", "body": "Mr Swinney has been named as the new SNP leader - and is now likely to become Scotland's next first minister after a vote in Holyrood later this week.\n\nJohn Swinney promised a \"new chapter\" as he took over as SNP leader, admitting his party has been through \"a rough time\".\n\nHe was speaking after being confirmed as the only candidate to succeed Humza Yousaf, who announced last Monday he was stepping down as both SNP leader and Scottish First Minister.\n\nHe insisted he was \"deeply honoured\" to take on the role, promising to \"give all that I have to serve my party and my country\".\n\nIt is the second time that Mr Swinney has been named as SNP leader - but this time he is also now likely to be declared as Scotland's new first minister following a vote in the Scottish Parliament later this week.\n\nBut after Mr Yousaf ended the powersharing agreement with the Scottish Greens, he will have to operate a minority administration at Holyrood.\n\nHere he promised to \"seek compromises that serve our nation well\" as he told the other parties at Holyrood that their opposition to independence was not a reason not to work with him on areas such as health, jobs and the economy.\n\nMr Swinney pledged he would \"seek to find common ground\" and \"join together in coalitions of the willing and solve the problems our country faces\".\n\nThe new SNP leader, who has already pledged to lead a centre-left government, told Scots: \"If elected first minister, my focus will be the economy, jobs, the cost of living. It will be the National Health Service, our schools and our public services. It will be addressing the climate crisis.\"\n\nHe said he would \"seek, with respect and courtesy, to persuade people of the case for independence\".\n\nBut he insisted that rival parties' opposition to this was \"not a reason for them to refuse to work with us to build the economy, support jobs and improve the health service\".\n\nHis appointment as SNP leader for a second time, having held the post between 2000 and 2004, comes exactly a week after Mr Yousaf's resignation.\n\nAt the start of his speech at Glasgow University on Monday, Mr Swinney paid tribute to his predecessor, hailing Mr Yousaf's \"moral leadership on the issue of Gaza\", adding he would \"continue to make a substantial contribution to the public life of Scotland\".\n\nBut he said his appointment to the post of SNP leader was \"the beginning of a new chapter\" for the party.\n\nWhile he said the SNP has \"faced a rough time recently as a party\" he insisted the fact that he was the only candidate to be the next leader \"demonstrates the Scottish National Party is now coming back together again now\".\n\nHe insisted he wanted to \"create a modern, diverse, dynamic Scotland\" as he added that the \"polarisation of politics does not serve our country well\".\n\nMr Swinney stated: \"Too often, too many people are too busy fighting to win battles when we should be seeking solutions to problems.\"\n\nHe continued: \"We need to stop shouting at each other and talk to each other. More than that, actually, we need to listen.\n\n\"And as first minister, I will do exactly that.\"\n\nMr Yousaf meanwhile congratulated his successor, as he urged SNP members to \"get behind John and his team so they can deliver for Scotland\".\n\nBut speaking about Mr Swinney, the Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said: \"It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\nThe Tory added: \"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession - the one issue they agree on - and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar hit out: \"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\n\n\"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure.\"\n\nSimilarly, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Alex Cole-Hamilton said: \"As his party's leader and a former wingman to both Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, John Swinney is now answerable for the SNP's appalling neglect of public services over the past 17 years.\n\n\"He should immediately announce a plan for cutting NHS waiting lists and stopping sewage flowing into our rivers and if he can't do that he should announce an election.\"", "source": {"uri": first minister at some point in the Holyrood schedule.\n\nMr Swinney would then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh before officially becoming first minister.\n\nThe 60-year-old served as Ms Sturgeon's deputy first minister for almost nine years.\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP was also SNP leader between 2000 and 2004, standing down after a poor {"uri": "8114047951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:31:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:31:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:25:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13387813/John-Swinney-promises-new-chapter-SNP-Scotland.html", "title": "John Swinney promises 'new chapter\u00b4 for the SNP and Scotland", "body": "John Swinney promised a \"new chapter\" as he took over as SNP leader, admitting his party has been through \"a rough time\".\n\nHe was speaking after being confirmed as the only candidate to succeed Humza Yousaf, who announced last Monday he was stepping down as both SNP leader and Scottish First Minister.\n\nHe insisted he was \"deeply honoured\" to take on the role, promising to \"give all that I have to serve my party and my country\".\n\nIt is the second time that Mr Swinney has been named as SNP leader - but this time he is also now likely to be declared as Scotland's new first minister following a vote in the Scottish Parliament later this week.\n\nBut after Mr Yousaf ended the powersharing agreement with the Scottish Greens, he will have to operate a minority administration at Holyrood.\n\nHere he promised to \"seek compromises that serve our nation well\" as he told the other parties at Holyrood that their opposition to independence was not a reason not to work with him on areas such as health, jobs and the economy.\n\nMr Swinney pledged he would \"seek to find common ground\" and \"join together in coalitions of the willing and solve the problems our country faces\".\n\nIt's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate Douglas Ross, Scottish Conservative leader\n\nThe new SNP leader, who has already pledged to lead a centre-left government, told Scots: \"If elected first minister, my focus will be the economy, jobs, the cost of living. It will be the National Health Service, our schools and our public services. It will be addressing the climate crisis.\"\n\nHe said he would \"seek, with respect and courtesy, to persuade people of the case for independence\".\n\nBut he insisted that rival parties' opposition to this was \"not a reason for them to refuse to work with us to build the economy, support jobs and improve the health service\".\n\nHis appointment as SNP leader for a second time, having held the post between 2000 and 2004, comes exactly a week after Mr Yousaf's resignation.\n\nAt the start of his speech at Glasgow University on Monday, Mr Swinney paid tribute to his predecessor, hailing Mr Yousaf's \"moral leadership on the issue of Gaza\", adding he would \"continue to make a substantial contribution to the public life of Scotland\".\n\nBut he said his appointment to the post of SNP leader was \"the beginning of a new chapter\" for the party.\n\nWhile he said the SNP has \"faced a rough time recently as a party\" he insisted the fact that he was the only candidate to be the next leader \"demonstrates the Scottish National Party is now coming back together again now\".\n\nHe insisted he wanted to \"create a modern, diverse, dynamic Scotland\" as he added that the \"polarisation of politics does not serve our country well\".\n\nMr Swinney stated: \"Too often, too many people are too busy fighting to win battles when we should be seeking solutions to problems.\"\n\nHe continued: \"We need to stop shouting at each other and talk to each other. More than that, actually, we need to listen.\n\n\"And as first minister, I will do exactly that.\"\n\nMr Yousaf meanwhile congratulated his successor, as he urged SNP members to \"get behind John and his team so they can deliver for Scotland\".\n\nBut speaking about Mr Swinney, the Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said: \"It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\nThe Tory added: \"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession - the one issue they agree on - and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"\n\nJohn Swinney previously served as SNP leader between 2000 and 2004. (Ben Curtis/PA)\n\nMeanwhile, Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar hit out: \"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\n\n\"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure.\"\n\nSimilarly, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Alex Cole-Hamilton said: \"As his party's leader and a former wingman to both Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, John Swinney is now answerable for the SNP's appalling neglect of public services over the past 17 years.\n\n\"He should immediately announce a plan for cutting NHS waiting lists and stopping sewage flowing into our rivers and if he can't do that he should announce an election.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, {"uri": "8113792927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:35:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:35:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:35:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2024/05/06/john-swinney-deeply-honoured-to-be-new-snp-leader/", "title": "John Swinney 'deeply honoured' to be new SNP leader", "body": "Mr Swinney succeeds Humza Yousaf in the post, and will almost certainly become Scotlan'ds next first minister later this week.\n\nFormer Scottish deputy first minister John Swinney said he was \"deeply honoured\" to have become the new leader of the SNP.\n\nMr Swinney reacted on social media after the party confirmed he was the only candidate to succeed Humza Yousaf, who announced one week ago he was stepping down as SNP leader and Scottish First Minister.\n\nMr Swinney is now expected to go on to become Scotland's seventh first minister, though before he does he will need to win the backing of MSPs in a vote at Holyrood.\n\nThat ballot could take place as early as Wednesday, with Mr Swinney likely to be officially in place in the top job in Scottish politics the following day.\n\nCommenting after it was confirmed he was the only candidate, Mr Swinney posted on X, formerly known as Twitter that he was \"deeply honoured to have been elected as Leader of @theSNP\".\n\nHe pledged: \"I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country.\"\n\nMr Yousaf's tenure as first minister came to an end after he tore up the powersharing agreement the party had enjoyed with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, which left him facing a vote of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nThat means Mr Swinney will have to lead a minority government at Holyrood, requiring support from other parties before vital legislation can proceed.\n\nMr Yousaf congratulated Mr Swinney as his successor as SNP leader and called on the party to heed his call for unity.\n\nHe posted on X, formerly Twitter: \"Congratulations to @JohnSwinney on becoming leader of @theSNP and FM-elect.\"\n\nJohn's central message has been one of unity. As a party, we must heed his call, whatever has happened in the past should remain there.\n\n\"Let's get behind John & his team so they can deliver for Scotland.\"\n\nIt is the second time that Mr Swinney has taken on the leadership of his party, having previously held the job from 2000 to 2004.\n\nBut then he was leader of the main opposition party at Holyrood, with a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in charge.\n\nNow, after holding a variety of senior posts in the Scottish Government, including finance secretary, education secretary and deputy first minister, a position he held for eight years under Nicola Sturgeon, he will get his first chance to be first minister.\n\nConfirmation of Mr Swinney's appointment as party leader comes 25 years to the day after the first elections to the Scottish Parliament with Mr Swinney one of only three MSPs to have held the same seat at Holyrood continuously since then.\n\nWhile Mr Yousaf's downfall was sparked by his decision to terminate the powersharing deal the SNP had had with the Scottish Greens, the smaller pro-independence party urged Mr Swinney not to ditch the \"progressive\" agenda that had been enshrined as part of that arrangement.\n\nScottish Green co-leader Patrick Harvie said the party's seven MSPs would meet to discuss how they would vote in the ballot for first minister.\n\nMr Harvie stated: \"We are committed to delivering on our vision of a fairer, greener and more equal Scotland, and are open to talks with John Swinney and his team about how we can work together to make that happen.\"\n\nHe added: \"Scotland needs a period of stable government.\n\n\"Mr Swinney knows that if he is to have our support then it must be on the basis of progressive policies that help us to tackle the climate crisis and build a fairer and more equal future.\"\n\nThe Green MSP added: \"There are a lot of important policies already on their way to delivery as a result of the Bute House Agreement, including better rights for tenants and rent controls, transforming the way we heat our homes and a watertight ban on conversion therapy.\n\n\"We remain utterly committed to these policies and will oppose any move away from them or steps to dilute them.\"\n\nScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross meanwhile urged Mr Swinney to \"govern for all of Scotland by abandoning his relentless push for independence\".\n\nMr Ross insisted his party would seek to \"hold John Swinney to account when he lets the Scottish people down - just as we've done with Humza Yousaf\".\n\nBut the Conservative added: \"It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\nWith Mr Swinney having led the SNP previously between 2000 and 2004, Mr Ross went on to question if a \"failed former leader from two decades ago - who, as education secretary, sent Scotland plummeting down international league tables\" was the best person to lead the country.\n\nHe claimed: \"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession, the one issue they agree on, and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"\n\nMeanwhile Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said \"John Swinney's coronation is entirely about managing the SNP rather than running our country and delivering for Scotland.\n\n\"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\"\n\nMr Sarwar said: \"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure.\n\n\"This is a stitch-up by a chaotic and dysfunctional party that is more interested in protecting its own interests than serving the interests of the people of Scotland.\"", {"uri": "8113682858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:23:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:23:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:22:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/john-swinney-named-leader-snp-112028010.html", "title": "John Swinney named new leader of SNP", "body": "John Swinney has become the new SNP leader after the party confirmed he was the only candidate for the role.\n\nThe party grandee, who had an unhappy previous stint as leader which ended 20 years ago, is expected to be voted in as Scotland's seventh first minister at Holyrood on Tuesday.\n\nThe SNP confirmed on Monday that Mr Swinney was the only candidate to reach the required level of support, which is 100 nominees from party members from at least 20 different branches.\n\nMr Swinney, who was Nicola Sturgeon's long-serving deputy, last week persuaded Kate Forbes, seen as his only viable contender after he decided to run, to support him after promising her a significant role in his government.\n\nGraeme McCormick, a party activist, had threatened to derail Mr Swinney's coronation but he was also convinced by Mr Swinney to stand down, following talks between the pair on Sunday.\n\nUnionist parties at Holyrood have accused the SNP of mounting a \"stich-up\" to install Mr Swinney without a contest.\n\nHe will be the third SNP first minister since Nicola Sturgeon won the 2021 Holyrood election.\n\nDespite the SNP demanding a UK general election after Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak were installed as prime ministers by the Tories, Mr Swinney has ruled out an early Holyrood election.\n\nHe is expected to hand Ms Forbes, who is on the right of the SNP, a prominent role in his government as part of a bid to unify his fractious party.\n\nKeith Brown, the SNP's deputy leader, claimed on Monday that Mr Swinney was \"the biggest hitter in the SNP\" and suggested unionist parties may come to regret toppling the unpopular Humza Yousaf.\n\nMr Yousaf was forced to resign as SNP leader and First Minister after his attempt to end his party's power-sharing pact with the Scottish Greens spectacularly backfired.\n\nThe smaller pro-independence party had planned to vote with unionist parties in a vote of no confidence against Mr Yousaf, leading to him standing down after only 13 months.\n\n\"I understand over the course of the weekend, we've people out canvassing and they've reported already an increase in positive turnout coming back from those canvassing sessions,\" Mr Brown claimed.\n\n\"So there's been an immediate lift from the discussions which John Swinney has had first of all with Kate Forbes and, it now appears, with Graeme McCormick.\"\n\nHowever, opponents claim Mr Swinney is tainted by his close association with Ms Sturgeon, who has described him as \"the best friend I could have wished for\".\n\nHe has also been associated with a number of controversies during his long period at the top of the SNP.\n\nIn the last parliament, he narrowly survived two confidence votes over botching exam results during the pandemic as Education Secretary and for refusing to release legal advice about the Alex Salmond affair.\n\nMr Swinney has also previously attempted to downplay questions over party finances. Police later launched an investigation which has seen Ms Sturgeon, who denies wrongdoing, arrested and released without charge.\n\nShe remains under investigation, along with Colin Beattle, the former party treasurer, who was also arrested last year and released without charge.\n\nMs Sturgeon's husband, Peter Murrell, the former SNP chief executive, was last month charged with embezzlement of funds from the party.\n\nMr Swinney is likely to become Scotland's next first minister, the third in just over a year, as early as Tuesday.\n\nThe Scottish Government Cabinet will also meet on Tuesday, with MSPs later given the opportunity to elect a new first minister at some point in the Holyrood schedule.\n\nMr Swinney would then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh before officially becoming First Minister.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113214667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:55:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:55:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:54:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://news.stv.tv/politics/john-swinney-favourite-to-become-new-snp-leader-and-first-minister-of-scotland-with-nominations-set-to-close", "title": "John Swinney remains sole candidate ahead of SNP nominations deadline", "body": "John Swinney is favourite to succeed Humza Yousaf as leader of the SNP, with just hours to go until nominations close.\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP will become the party's new leader from Monday afternoon if he remains the only candidate to have put his name forward by midday.\n\nBut reports suggest a leadership battle may be on the cards after activist Graeme McCormick used the independence march in Glasgow to drum up support for his candidacy.\n\nIt is understood that McCormick believes he is very likely to receive the 100 nominations from at least 20 SNP branches before the Monday deadline.\n\nIf he won the leadership race against Swinney, he would not be able to become First Minister as he is not elected in the Scottish Parliament, with McCormick reportedly telling members he believes the roles should be run by two different individuals.\n\nAs things stand, Swinney remains the only confirmed candidate and - if that remains the case - he will automatically become leader of the SNP at 12.01pm.\n\nAt that point, as leader of the largest group in Holyrood with 63 out of 129 seats, he will seek to become the First Minister.\n\nBut will need the support of a majority of MSPs - of which he is two short.\n\nWith Scottish Labour, the Tories and the Liberal Democrats certain to vote for their own leaders, he will have to rely on the only other major party in Holyrood - the Scottish Greens.\n\nThat's the same party that ultimately led to Yousaf's resignation after he ended their power-sharing deal, kicking Greens co-leaders Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater out of government in the process.\n\nBut the Greens have made it clear their issue was with Yousaf - and not the wider Scottish Government.\n\nMSPs could vote through Swinney - or reject him - as soon as Tuesday.\n\nIf he wins more votes for than against him he should be formally sworn in shortly afterwards.\n\nHe will then take part in a short ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh - taking the oath of office, known as an \"official declaration\", and pledging allegiance to the King.\n\nIt means his inaugural First Minister's Questions could be held on Thursday - less than two weeks after Yousaf's resignation.\n\nSwinney's looming ascension to Bute House - the official residence of the First Minister - has already prompted anger from opposition parties.\n\nHe represents the third FM in just one election cycle.\n\nThe 2021 Scottish Parliament election was contested when Nicola Sturgeon was SNP leader.\n\nWhen she resigned, Yousaf took over and a year later Swinney looks like he will win the SNP leadership unopposed.\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar has said the SNP \"cannot impose another unelected leader on Scotland\" and called for a national ballot to be held.\n\nAnd Alex Cole-Hamilton, the leader of the Scottish Lib Dems, said \"we need a Scottish general election now\" while the Tories have said they would \"welcome\" a public vote.\n\nOpposition MSPs also point to SNP politicians accusing Westminster of being anti-democratic for having three leaders after just one election.\n\nSwinney has so far refused calls for an election, saying Holyrood has a fixed-parliament term and that ultimately MSPs decide who the First Minister is, unlike in Westminster where there is no such vote.\n\nCole-Hamilton says Swinney has \"more baggage than an airport carousel\" while Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said the SNP had gone \"back to the future\". Scottish Labour described him as \"yesterday's man\".\n\nSwinney has been keen to shed that image.\n\nAt his campaign launch in Edinburgh, he signalled that the party under him would return to a more centrist position focusing on \"economic growth and social justice\".\n\nThat comes after Sturgeon's deal with the Greens and a number of contentious policies such as gender reforms, the deposit return scheme and higher taxes on middle and higher earners.\n\nHe also offered an olive branch to Kate Forbes - considered to be on the right of the party - and has seemingly won over MPs such as Joanna Cherry, who has been critical of the party's social policies under Sturgeon and Yousaf.\n\nSwinney said Forbes would play a \"significant role\" in his government.\n\nLater, Forbes said she would not run and offered a full-hearted endorsement of Swinney.\n\nIt means Swinney has won support from several different wings of the SNP.\n\n\"I want to build on the work of the SNP government to create a modern, diverse, dynamic Scotland that will ensure opportunity for all of her citizens,\" he said at his SNP leadership launch on Thursday.\n\n\"I want to unite the SNP and unite Scotland for independence.\"\n\nHe added: \"Only the SNP stand where the majority of people want their government to be, in the moderate centre left of Scottish politics.\n\n\"That is where I stand and if elected by my party and by parliament my goals as First Minister will come straight from that centre-left tradition - the pursuit of economic growth and social justice.\"\n\nFor opposition parties, Swinney will always be tied to records of Alex Salmond - he was his finance secretary for his whole premiership - and Sturgeon - he was her deputy first minster throughout her entire nine years as leader.\n\nWhose directions he chooses to follow - or none - is a choice he has yet to make.", "source": {"uri": "news.stv.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "STV News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.ludlowadvertiser.co.uk/news/national/24301399.john-swinney-deeply-honoured-new-snp-leader/", "title": "John Swinney 'deeply honoured' to be new SNP leader", "body": "Former Scottish deputy first minister John Swinney said he was \"deeply honoured\" to have become the new leader of the SNP.\n\nMr Swinney reacted on social media after the party confirmed he was the only candidate to succeed Humza Yousaf, who announced one week ago he was stepping down as SNP leader and Scottish First Minister.\n\nMr Swinney is now expected to go on to become Scotland's seventh first minister, though before he does he will need to win the backing of MSPs in a vote at Holyrood.\n\nThat ballot could take place as early as Wednesday, with Mr Swinney likely to be officially in place in the top job in Scottish politics the following day.\n\nCommenting after it was confirmed he was the only candidate, Mr Swinney posted on X, formerly known as Twitter that he was \"deeply honoured to have been elected as Leader of @theSNP\".\n\nHe pledged: \"I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country.\"\n\nMr Yousaf's tenure as first minister came to an end after he tore up the powersharing agreement the party had enjoyed with the Scottish Greens at Holyrood, which left him facing a vote of no confidence in his leadership.\n\nThat means Mr Swinney will have to lead a minority government at Holyrood, requiring support from other parties before vital legislation can proceed.\n\nIt is the second time that Mr Swinney has taken on the leadership of his party, having previously held the job from 2000 to 2004.\n\nBut then he was leader of the main opposition party at Holyrood, with a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition in charge.\n\nNow, after holding a variety of senior posts in the Scottish Government, including finance secretary, education secretary and deputy first minister, a position he held for eight years under Nicola Sturgeon, he will get his first chance to be first minister.\n\nConfirmation of Mr Swinney's appointment as party leader comes 25 years to the day after the first elections to the Scottish Parliament with Mr Swinney one of only three MSPs to have held the same seat at Holyrood continuously since then.\n\nWhile Mr Yousaf's downfall was sparked by his decision to terminate the powersharing deal the SNP had had with the Scottish Greens, the smaller pro-independence party urged Mr Swinney not to ditch the \"progressive\" agenda that had been enshrined as part of that arrangement.\n\nScottish Green co-leader Patrick Harvie said the party's seven MSPs would meet to discuss how they would vote in the ballot for first minister.\n\nMr Harvie stated: \"We are committed to delivering on our vision of a fairer, greener and more equal Scotland, and are open to talks with John Swinney and his team about how we can work together to make that happen.\"\n\nHe added: \"Scotland needs a period of stable government.\n\n\"Mr Swinney knows that if he is to have our support then it must be on the basis of progressive policies that help us to tackle the climate crisis and build a fairer and more equal future.\"\n\nThe Green MSP added: \"There are a lot of important policies already on their way to delivery as a result of the Bute House Agreement, including better rights for tenants and rent controls, transforming the way we heat our homes and a watertight ban on conversion therapy.\n\n\"We remain utterly committed to these policies and will oppose any move away from them or steps to dilute them.\"\n\nScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross meanwhile urged Mr Swinney to \"govern for all of Scotland by abandoning his relentless push for independence\".\n\nMr Ross insisted his party would seek to \"hold John Swinney to account when he lets the Scottish people down - just as we've done with Humza Yousaf\".\n\nBut the Conservative added: \"It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\"\n\nWith Mr Swinney having led the SNP previously between 2000 and 2004, Mr Ross went on to question if a \"failed former leader from two decades ago - who, as education secretary, sent Scotland plummeting down international league tables\" was the best person to lead the country.\n\nHe claimed: \"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession, the one issue they agree on, and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"\n\nMeanwhile Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said \"John Swinney's coronation is entirely about managing the SNP rather than running our country and delivering for Scotland.\n\n\"At a time when Scotland is crying out for change, the SNP is offering more of the same.\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years.\"\n\nMr Sarwar said: \"From presiding over the exam results scandal as education secretary to destroying public finances as finance secretary, John Swinney's record is one of failure.\n\n\"This is a stitch-up by a chaotic and dysfunctional party that is more interested in protecting its own interests than serving the interests of the people of Scotland.\"", "source": {"uri": "ludlowadvertiser.co.uk", {"uri": "8112263895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:31:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:31:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:29:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/swinney-warns-snp-cohesion-amid-111749288.html", "title": "Swinney warns of SNP cohesion amid challenge reports", "body": "The front-runner for the SNP leadership has suggested rebuilding the party could be delayed if another candidate enters the race.\n\nJohn Swinney told BBC Scotland the SNP has not been as cohesive as it should have been and had endured a \"rough couple of years\".\n\nIt comes amid reports that veteran SNP activist Graeme McCormick, who is openly critical of the Scottish government, has collected enough signatures to stand against Mr Swinney.\n\nMr McCormick, who has declined to speak to the BBC, is thought to have canvassed for support at an independence march in Glasgow on Saturday.\n\nMr Swinney, the former deputy first minister and party leader, could be elected within days, with the deadline for candidates to declare at midday on Monday.\n\nCandidates must have 100 nominations from at least 20 local party branches.\n\nAsked whether he would welcome another leadership contest given reports about Mr McCormick, Mr Swinney said: \"I think it would be better if we just got on with things, that we started the rebuilding of the SNP and its political strength.\"\n\nHe told The Sunday Show: \"We had a lot of strains around a couple of issues in parliament and I think we've just had a rough couple of years.\n\n\"The party has been engaging but frankly, we've not been as cohesive as we should have been. That's been obvious to the public.\n\n\"The SNP has not looked cohesive, the SNP has not looked together - the central point of my message is we've got to get ourselves together.\"\n\nMr McCormick is a retired lawyer who stood against Mike Russell to become party president in 2023, losing by 599 votes to 79.\n\nHe previously argued for abolishing tax and replacing it with an annual rent on land, and that the route to Scottish independence lay through international treaties, with Scotland dissolving the union immediately if the SNP returned the most MPs in Scotland at a general election.\n\nIn a speech at the party conference he described the SNP government as being like \"flatulence in a trance.\"\n\nMr Swinney is the only declared candidate so far to succeed Humza Yousaf, who announced he would stand down after ending a power-sharing agreement with the Scottish Greens.\n\nThe abrupt end of the Bute House Agreement came two days after Mr Yousaf said he had no intention of doing so, and left him facing two votes of no confidence.\n\nThe move angered the Greens, who had previously criticised the Scottish government for scrapping key climate targets and pausing puberty blockers for under 18s referred by the country's specialist gender clinic.\n\nLast year, Mr Yousaf only secured a narrow win over Kate Forbes in an often fractious SNP leadership contest - despite being Nicola Sturgeon's chosen successor.\n\nMr Swinney - who secured Kate Forbes' backing and has offered her a \"significant\" role in his government - said he wants to bring the party together after the last \"difficult\" leadership election.\n\nHe also said he is \"physically and mentally ready\" for the role, after he decided not to stand in the 2023 leadership contest.\n\nMr Swinney previously led the party for four years in opposition from 2000 to 2004.\n\nIf elected, he said he would seek to govern on a \"moderate centre left\" platform, and that he would be open to working with any other political party in the parliament to pass legislation.\n\nLast year Mr Swinney told the BBC's Nicola Sturgeon podcast that he had been trying to stand down from government since 2016.\n\nHowever he said he had been persuaded to run on this occasion after discussions with his family.\n\nHe chose not to run in 2023 as he felt \"tired and drained\" after a number of years in important roles, but that he was feeling refreshed after a year out of the cabinet.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I thought it was time for other people to take leading roles... I thought I'd done my bit.\"\n\nHowever he said he now had \"peace of mind\" that running would be the \"right thing to do for me and my family, and my party and my country.\"\n\nThe Perthshire North MSP added that he was confident he would deliver independence, and that he would aim to do this through \"reasoned conversation\".\n\nScottish Conservative chairman Craig Hoy said it was \"laughable\" that Mr Swinney wanted to take conflict out of a push for independence.\n\nHe said: \"Scotland needs a first minister focused on the public's real priorities - fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy - not one fixated on dividing the nation just to pacify the warring SNP.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [],
