{"uri": "2024-05-346524333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:16:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:16:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:07:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/what-are-the-key-challenges-facing-john-swinney-as-first-minister-and-snp-leader-4617689", "title": "What are the key challenges facing John Swinney as First Minister and SNP leader?", "body": "John Swinney will not have his troubles to seek. The new SNP leader, who will become Scotland's seventh First Minister this week, inherits a number of problems both in his party and in the country at large. He will be all too aware of the difficulties ahead.\n\nHis predecessor, Humza Yousaf, never really managed to get on the front foot. Within days of him taking office last year, the police investigation into the SNP's funding and finances exploded into the headlines. It has haunted the party ever since.\n\nMr Swinney will seek to heal internal divisions and boost his party's fortunes in the polls ahead of an expected general election later this year. He has also emphasised the importance of economic growth. So what are the key challenges he faces?\n\nA clear vision\n\nMr Swinney will want to set out a clear strategic direction for his party. This is something his predecessor arguably struggled to do. Mr Yousaf hiked income tax for higher earners at the same time as freezing council tax, which some saw as sending a muddled message.\n\n\"Is this a guy who has demonstrated clear strategic direction?\" asked polling expert Professor Sir John Curtice when I spoke to him last month. \"Answer: no. Increases one set of taxes and reduces another set of taxes.\"\n\nAt his leadership campaign launch last week, Mr Swinney said his goals as First Minister \"will come straight from that moderate centre-left tradition - the pursuit of economic growth and of social justice\".\n\nPolicy rows\n\nMr Swinney referenced the \"curse\" of child poverty, as well as the need to bring people and businesses \"with us\" in the pursuit of net zero.\n\n\"I want ministers to be focused on the delivery of services on which the public depend - on health, on education, on housing, on transport - so people see their lives are getting better as a result of the actions of their government,\" he told supporters last week.\n\nThe Scottish Government has been embroiled in a number of policy rows in recent months. Prof Curtice said SNP ministers have had \"a wee bit, seemingly, of a reverse Midas touch\", adding: \"They cannot stop the mud being stuck on them.\"\n\nWill Mr Swinney seek to steer away from controversial issues such as gender reform and conversion therapy in order to focus resources elsewhere? Polling shows there are real concerns about areas such as health and education in Scotland.\n\nMinority government\n\nFollowing the end of the power-sharing deal between the SNP and the Greens, Mr Swinney will not have a parliamentary majority. This is not necessarily a huge stumbling block - after all, both Alex Salmond and Ms Sturgeon previously presided over minority administrations.\n\nHowever, as Mr Swinney acknowledged, it does mean his party's approach will have to change. The Greens have said they will engage on an \"issue by issue basis\". Depending on what Mr Swinney chooses to pursue, there could be some rocky ground ahead.\n\nGeneral election\n\nThe SNP potentially faces a tough general election in a few months' time. Polls show support for the SNP has slipped, while Labour is on the rise in Scotland. The Rutherglen and Hamilton West by-election last year saw a huge 20.4 per cent swing from the SNP to Labour.\n\nOnce a narrative takes hold in politics, it can be hard to shift. Can Mr Swinney turn things around?\n\nParty unity\n\nAt his leadership launch, Mr Swinney said the SNP \"is not as cohesive\" as it needs to be.\n\n\"I could have stood back and hoped others would sort things out,\" he said. \"But I care too much about the future of Scotland and the Scottish National Party to walk on by. Just as we must fight against the polarisation of our politics, we cannot allow the SNP to be polarised.\"\n\nThe modern SNP was once renowned for its iron discipline, but divisions have been increasingly apparent in recent years. Figures such as Joanna Cherry, the high-profile MP, and Fergus Ewing, the former minister who is now a backbench rebel, have been outspoken critics of the party's leadership.\n\nGender reform and the SNP's power-sharing deal with the Greens were both sources of controversy. But there have also been disagreements over independence strategy, as well as a wider dissatisfaction in some quarters with the direction of the party.\n\nMr Swinney recognises he will need to \"bring the SNP back together again\".\n\nIndependence\n\nMr Yousaf's independence strategy was an unrealistic compromise designed to appease the restless factions within his own party. Under his plan, winning a majority of Scottish seats at the general election would have given the SNP a mandate to push for a second independence referendum.\n\nIn reality, neither Labour nor the Tories would have agreed to this.\n\nMr Swinney has instead stressed the need to build public support. \"What I think our priority has got to be, is to spend less time discussing the mechanics and the thresholds about independence, but to start winning the arguments about why independence is an absolute necessity for people in Scotland,\" he said over the weekend.\n\nHe rejected Mr Yousaf's claim that independence is \"frustratingly close\". But will SNP members lose patience if progress remains stalled?\n\nOperation Branchform\n\nThen there's the ongoing police investigation into the SNP's funding and finances.\n\nMr Murrell was arrested for a second time last month and charged with embezzlement of SNP funds. Party insiders are naturally braced for any further police activity.\n\nUntil the probe is brought to a close, it will continue to cast a shadow over the party.", "source": {"uri": "scotsman.com", veteran John Swinney on Monday was named head of the pro-independence SNP party, leaving him poised to become Scotland's leader.\n\nSwinney, 60, said on X, formerly Twitter, he was \"deeply honored to have been elected as leader of the SNP\" after Humza Yousaf resigned last week after little more than a year as Scottish leader and head of the Scottish National Party (SNP).\n\nThe SNP confirmed Swinney's election after nominations for the post closed at 12 noon (1100 GMT) without any other challengers emerging.\n\nHumza stepped down last Monday as he faced a confidence vote in the Scottish parliament that he was set to lose having ditched his junior coalition partners, the Scottish Green Party, in a row over climate policy.\n\nSwinney is likely to become the next first minister, head of the devolved Scottish government, but will still need enough votes in the Scottish parliament to be elected first minister.\n\nLaunching his bid last week, Swinney said he was running \"to unite the SNP and unite Scotland for independence\", despite polls showing stalled support for a split from the UK.\n\n\"I want to build on the work of the SNP government to create a modern, diverse, dynamic Scotland that will ensure opportunity for all of our citizens,\" Swinney told supporters in Edinburgh.\n\nSwinney inherits a difficult political legacy with former SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal and a challenging domestic policy landscape.\n\nWith the SNP heading a minority government in the 129-seat Scottish parliament, he will need the support of another party to SNP leader - and likely new Scottish...", "body": "John Swinney, who was for over eight years deputy first minister at Holyrood, now seems certain to take on the top job in Scottish politics.\n\nBut as first minister he is sure to face a bulging in-tray, packed with issues to address, when he enters Bute House.\n\nPerhaps the first task facing him in his new role will be to appoint the cabinet team who will support him as part of the Scottish Government.\n\nA veteran of the Scottish Government since the SNP, Mr Swinney has already held many of the key posts, including having served as finance secretary, and education secretary, so will know what is expected of those he appoints to serve under him.\n\nA new Scottish cabinet could be announced as early as Thursday, with all eyes on what post could be given to Kate Forbes, who like Mr Swinney has previously been in charge of the finance brief for the Scottish Government.\n\nShe had ran to be SNP leader and first minister when Nicola Sturgeon stepped down, coming a close second to Humza Yousaf.\n\nSNP MSP Kate Forbes is expected to get a top role (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nThis time round however she declined to stand, instead backing Mr Swinney and appointing her to a key post in the Scottish Government could also help the new SNP leader with another task he faced, that of uniting his party.\n\nMs Forbes is amongst a group of SNP MSPs who have spoken out against several of the policies pursued and promoted by the Scottish Greens while in government, such as gender recognition reforms, which were blocked by Westminster, and highly protected marine areas, a policy which was ditched by the Scottish Government after attracting criticism from the fishing sector and others.\n\nWhile Ms Forbes refused to serve in Mr Yousaf's cabinet team, bringing her back into the heart of government could help appease those within the SNP who had been concerned about the role the Greens played in power.\n\nWith the powersharing agreement with the Greens no longer in place, Mr Swinney will be forced to lead a minority government at Holyrood.\n\nAs part of this role he will have to work with other parties in the Scottish Parliament on an issue by issue basis if he wants legislation to be passed by Holyrood.\n\nHe acknowledged this when he announced he was running for the SNP leadership, saying his party must now \"work to seek common ground in the Scottish Parliament in the interests of the public and of good governance\".\n\nMr Swinney added that as a result, the party's approach in Holyrood would \"have to change, to listen, to compromise, to work with all other political parties\".\n\nAs new SNP leader he will have lead his party in what could likely prove to be a difficult general election campaign later this year.\n\nPolls suggest the SNP could lose seats at Westminster, with the party facing a challenge from a revived Scottish Labour Party in the battle for votes.\n\nMeanwhile his appointment {"uri": "8111655524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:06:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:06:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:06:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/05/05/snp-running-scared-of-electorate-with-refusal-to-call-election--labour/", "title": "SNP running scared of electorate with refusal to call election - Labour", "body": "John Swinney is likely to become the third first minister in just over a year next week.\n\nThe SNP is \"running scared\" of the Scottish people by rejecting calls for a Holyrood election, Scottish Labour has said.\n\nAnnouncing his candidacy for the SNP leadership on Thursday, Mr Swinney dismissed the push for the country to go to the polls as a \"red herring\".\n\nBut Scottish Labour deputy leader Dame Jackie Baillie said there should be a Holyrood poll as well as the upcoming UK general election \"to boot both of Scotland's failing governments out for good\".\n\nShe added: \"Scotland's public services are in chaos and the ruling SNP is in disarray - but all they are offering Scots is yesterday's man and serial failure John Swinney.\n\n\"When the Tories began their revolving door policy in Downing Street the SNP rightly demanded an election, but now they are saying Scots should put up and shut up with a revolving door in Bute House.\n\n\"No Scot voted for first minister John Swinney or the latest collection of SNP politicians that will make up the next cabinet.\n\n\"The SNP is denying democracy - that position is untenable.\n\n\"It's clear for all to see that they are running scared of the verdict of the Scottish people.\"\n\nMr Swinney looks set to become first minister next week following a tumultuous period in Scottish politics.\n\nCurrent incumbent Humza Yousaf announced last Monday he would step down rather than face a no confidence vote in Holyrood which he may have lost.\n\nMr Swinney and former finance secretary Kate Forbes - who Mr Yousaf defeated in last year's leadership contest - quickly emerged as the front-runners to replace him.\n\nBut Ms Forbes ruled herself out on Thursday and instead looks set to take up a key place in Mr Swinney's government, should he win the leadership and subsequently be elected first minister.\n\nNominations for the SNP's top job close on Monday at noon, with Mr Swinney to be declared the winner if no other candidate gains the 100 signatures from 20 different branches required to run.\n\nA spokesman for the SNP said: \"Calls from Jackie Baillie for a Holyrood election are completely hypocritical. Just last month the Labour Party appointed a new First Minister in Wales with no election held.\n\n\"There is a difference between Westminster and Holyrood electoral systems. We have a fixed-term parliamentary system at Holyrood.\n\n\"In Westminster, MPs don't elect who the Prime Minister is; however at Holyrood, MSPs do elect the first minister.\n\n\"There will be a vote close at noon in the race to replace Humza Yousaf as the leader of the SNP.\n\nThere were reports of a potential contest on Sunday when activist Graeme McCormick said he had the secured 100 nominations from 20 branches needed to run against Mr Swinney.\n\nBut later on Sunday, he confirmed he had backed out of the campaign after \"lengthy and fruitful\" conversations with Mr Swinney.\n\nMr Swinney, a former deputy first minister, had warned earlier that a contest could damage the party's chances of recovering from a \"difficult\" period.\n\nSpeaking to the BBC's Good Morning Scotland radio programme, Mr Brown said it is important to respect the SNP's democratic processes.\n\nWith a few hours to go until the nomination deadline closes, Mr Brown said: \"It seems to be that the field is cleaning somewhat and it looks like John Swinney might be the sole nominee.\"\n\nMr Brown described Mr Swinney as the \"biggest hitter in the SNP\" who would scare unionist parties \"to a great extent\".\n\nHe continued: \"I also understand over the course of the weekend, of course, we've people out canvassing and they've reported already an increase in positive turnout coming back from those canvassing sessions.\n\n\"So there's been an immediate lift from the discussions which John Swinney has had first of all with Kate Forbes and, it now appears, with Graeme McCormick.\"\n\nIt was also initially thought that former finance secretary Ms Forbes would contest the leadership, but Mr Swinney heaped praised on his potential rival, saying she would be offered a \"significant\" job in his team after she confirmed she would not run against him.\n\nAssuming there are no last-minute challengers, the leadership bid will not have to be put to SNP members, with Mr Swinney clear to take over.\n\nHe is likely to become Scotland's next first minister, the third in just over a year, as early as Tuesday.\n\nThe Scottish Government Cabinet will meet on Tuesday, with MSPs later given the opportunity to elect a new first minister at some point in the Holyrood schedule.\n\nMr Swinney would then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh I am no interim leader.\n\n\"I am offering to lead my party through the Westminster elections and to lead us beyond the 2026 elections -- two contests which I intend to win for the SNP, and for Scotland.\n\n\"My message is crisp and simple: I am stepping forward to bring the SNP together, deliver economic growth and social justice, and to deliver the very best future for everyone in a modern, dynamic, diverse Scotland.\"\n\nQuestioned on Ms Forbes's leadership ambitions, Mr Swinney praised her as \"intelligent, creative, thoughtful person who has much to contribute.\"\n\nHe added: {"uri": "8113756328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:15:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:15:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:11:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13387151/What-happens-John-Swinney.html", "title": "What happens next for John Swinney?", "body": "Becoming the new leader of the SNP does not mean John Swinney will automatically become Scotland's next first minister.\n\nFor that to happen the former deputy first minister has to face a vote in the Scottish Parliament, where he will need to win the support of MSPs.\n\nIt is likely other party leaders could put themselves forward for the ballot, though it is in reality unlikely that they would be successful in this.\n\nHowever for Mr Swinney to win the vote in Holyrood, which could take place as early as Wednesday, he will need some MSPs from opposition parties to either back him in the vote, or at least abstain.\n\nMSPs could vote on Wednesday to decide who should become the next first minister. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nThat is because without the powersharing deal with the Scottish Greens, which was ripped up by Humza Yousaf, the SNP is short of an overall majority in the Scottish Parliament.\n\nThe support of Scottish Greens therefore could still be crucial going forward, in this vote and in others to come at Holyrood.\n\nAssuming he wins the vote, Mr Swinney will then become the Scottish Parliament's nominated candidate to be the country's seventh first minister.\n\nAfter that he would be formally appointed via a royal warrant, a legal document that is authorised by the King.\n\nFollowing that he would officially be sworn into the post in a ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh by the Lord President, Scotland's most senior judge.\n\nAfter being praised by Mr Swinney when he announced he was running to be SNP leader, former finance secretary Kate Forbes could play a key role in his government team. (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nThat could happen on Thursday morning with Mr Swinney then potentially going on to take First Minister's Questions for the first time in the new role at noon the same day.\n\nHe will also have to appoint his his ministerial team of cabinet secretaries and junior ministers, with much attention on what position will go to Kate Forbes.\n\nThe former Holyrood finance secretary had been tipped as a possible challenger to Mr Swinney for the SNP leadership, but announced on Thursday she would not stand and would instead back the former deputy first minister in his bid for the top job.\n\nMr Swinney, in announcing his candidacy sought to praise Ms Forbes, who last year ran Mr Yousaf a close second in the contest to succeed Nicola Sturgeon, and giving her a top post in his cabinet team would be seen as a move towards restoring unity within the different factions of the SNP.\n\nMs Forbes has been out of the Scottish cabinet since then, but could return to a senior post run against Swinney.\n\nBut later on Sunday, he confirmed he had backed out of the campaign after \"lengthy and fruitful\" conversations with Swinney.\n\nSwinney, a former deputy first minister, had {"uri": "8111829424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:51:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:51:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24298666.labour-pushes-holyrood-election-swinney-cusp-fm/", "title": "SNP leadership: Veteran activist in bid to stop John Swinney's coronation", "body": "Graeme McCormick is confident he can secure enough nominations from party members to trigger a race.\n\nWhile Mr Swinney would almost certainly win any vote by a considerable margin, a battle would delay his move into Bute House until the end of the month.\n\nREAD MORE: M\u00e0iri McAllan: SNP did not want another 'bruising' contest\n\nAnyone looking to enter the contest needs the support of 100 members from 20 different branches by tomorrow's noon deadline.\n\nAccording to the Yours For Scotland website, Mr McCormick, a retired Conveyancing solicitor who has served as Convener of SNP's Dumbarton branch, had secured the support of 40 members from 20 different branches by Thursday night.\n\nHe was at the All Under One Banner independence rally in Glasgow Green yesterday with his nomination forms.\n\nHe declined to comment when approached by The Herald on Sunday but indicated he was very confident he would meet the threshold.\n\nThe SNP's ruling NEC has already said that if there is more than one candidate then the vote will run between 13 and 27 May.\n\nIt is likely there will be hustings across Scotland. There were nine during last year's six-week contest.\n\nMr McCormick made headlines last October when he described the SNP's plan to secure independence as \"flatulence in a trance.\"\n\nA spokesperson for Mr Swinney said: \"John Swinney has pledged to unite the SNP and has made clear his determination to ensure there is open and respectful debate in the SNP on key policy questions.\"\n\nHumza Yousaf was also preparing to step down this week, but if a contest is triggered he will remain in charge of the government for another three weeks.\n\nREAD MORE: UNSPUN \ud83d\uddf3\ufe0f Swinney wanted election with Tory leader change. He should call one\n\nMeanwhile, Scottish Labour has repeated its demand for the next first minister to call an immediate Holyrood election.\n\nMr Swinney could be the third SNP leader since the 2021 election.\n\nAsked about the prospect of an early vote during his campaign launch on Friday, he said it was a \"red herring\" as the Scottish Parliament's fixed terms meant there would be an election in 2026 whatever happened.\n\n\"We should see out the term. We should respect the fact we operate in a fixed-term parliamentary system where there can be a change of personnel within that period,\" he said.\n\nScottish Labour deputy leader Jackie Baillie accused the SNP of hypocrisy. She pointed to comments made by Nicola Sturgeon in October 2022, when Rishi Sunak replaced Liz Truss.\n\n\"The governance of any country cannot simply be a revolving door that one party gets to pick time and time again who occupies the highest office in the land,\" the former first minister said at the time.\n\nCalling for the vote, Dame Jackie said: \"Scotland's public services are in chaos and the ruling SNP is in disarray - but all they are offering Scots is yesterday's man and serial failure John Swinney.\n\n\"When the Tories began their revolving door policy in Downing St the SNP rightly demanded an election - but now they are saying Scots should put up and shut up with a revolving door in Bute House.\n\n\"No Scot voted for First Minister John Swinney or the latest collection of SNP politicians that will make up the next cabinet.\n\n\"The SNP is denying democracy - that position is untenable.\n\n\"It's clear for all to see that they are running scared of the verdict of the Scottish people.\"\n\nAn SNP spokesperson said the situation in Westminster with the Tory leadership change was not comparable to their leadership change in Holyrood.\n\nThey said: \"Calls from Jackie Baillie for a Holyrood election are completely hypocritical.\n\n\"Just last month the Labour party appointed a new First Minister in Wales with no election held.\n\n\"There is a difference between Westminster and Holyrood electoral systems. We have a fixed term parliamentary system at Holyrood.\n\n\"In Westminster, MPs don't elect who the Prime Minister is; however at Holyrood, MSPs do elect the First Minister.\n\n\"There will be a vote "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://thefrontierpost.com/political-veteran-set-to-be-named-scotlands-next-leader/", "title": "Political veteran set to be named Scotland's next leader", "body": "Edinburgh (AFP): Scottish political veteran John Swinney on Monday was named head of the pro-independence SNP party, leaving him poised to become Scotland's new leader.\n\nSwinney, 60, said on X, formerly Twitter, he was \"deeply honoured to have been elected as leader of the SNP\" after Humza Yousaf resigned last week after little more than a year as Scottish leader and head of the Scottish National Party (SNP).\n\nThe SNP confirmed Swinney's election after nominations for the post closed at noon (1100 GMT) without any other challengers emerging.\n\nHumza stepped down last Monday as he faced a confidence vote in the Scottish parliament that he was set to lose having ditched his junior coalition partners, the Scottish Green Party, in a row over climate policy.\n\nSwinney is likely to become the next First Minister, head of the devolved Scottish government, but will still need enough votes in the Scottish parliament to be elected first minister.\n\nLaunching his bid last week, Swinney said he was running \"to unite the SNP and unite Scotland for independence\", despite polls showing stalled support for a split from the UK.\n\n\"I want to build on the work of the SNP government to create a modern, diverse, dynamic Scotland that will ensure opportunity for all of our citizens,\" Swinney told supporters in Edinburgh.\n\nSwinney is an old party hand who led the SNP from 2000 to 2004 when the party was in opposition.\n\nBut he inherits a difficult political legacy, with former SNP leader and ally Nicola Sturgeon embroiled in a party funding scandal and a challenging domestic policy landscape.\n\n- Loss of momentum -\n\nCritics have accused the SNP, in power in Edinburgh for 17 years, of focusing on pursuing independence at the expense of issues like the cost-of-living crisis and health.\n\nThe party has struggled to rebuild momentum for another independence vote since Scotland voted against leaving the UK in a referendum in 2014.\n\nSupport for independence, meanwhile, has since fallen to between 41 and 43 percent, according to three opinion polls taken in April.\n\nWith the SNP heading a minority government in the 129-seat Scottish parliament, Swinney will need the support of another party to form a governing coalition or to pass legislation.\n\nThe government is currently two votes short of an overall majority, only surviving the no-confidence vote brought by the Labour opposition last week thanks to the backing of the Greens.\n\nThe ructions in the SNP are being closely watched in London, ahead of a UK general election later this year.\n\nThe SNP currently holds 43 seats in the UK parliament.\n\nThe UK's main Labour opposition is hoping for a resurgence in its former stronghold north of the English border to help it win an outright majority in the general election.\n\nThe Scottish Parliament, re-established in 1999, has limited powers to set policy in areas such as health, education, transport and the difficulty.\n\nA swearing-in ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh could take place as early as Wednesday, with Mr Swinney then taking First Minister's Questions on Thursday.\n\nThe leadership contest was triggered after Mr Yousaf confirmed his intention to resign last Monday.\n\nHis position became untenable after his shock decision to end the SNP's powersharing agreement with the Scottish Greens.\n\nNominations in the leadership closed at noon.\n\nOver the weekend, there was speculation that activist Graeme McCormick could mount a bid after he secured the necessary number of nominations from members.\n\nBut late on Sunday he said he would back out of the contest after a \"lengthy and fruitful\" conversation with Mr Swinney.\n\nThe SNP's depute leader, Keith Brown said the \"biggest hitter\" to take charge.\n\nSpeaking to the BBC's Good Morning Scotland radio programme, Mr Brown said it is important to respect the SNP's democratic processes.\n\nHe said: \"It seems to be that the field is cleaning somewhat and it looks like John Swinney might be the sole nominee.\"\n\nMr Brown described Mr Swinney as the \"biggest hitter in the SNP\" who would scare unionist parties {"uri": "2024-05-346436213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:56:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:56:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:16:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/27756097/john-swinney-confirmed-as-snp-leader/", "title": "SNP veteran John Swinney confirmed as party's new leader", "body": "JOHN Swinney has been crowned as the SNP's new leader after it was confirmed he would not be opposed in his bid to succeed Humza Yousaf.\n\nThe veteran Nat staved off a late attempt by a party activist to challenge him for the position, avoiding the prospect of a leadership contest.\n\nAs leader of the largest party at Holyrood, Mr Swinney is now set to be voted in by MSPs on Tuesday before officially being sworn in as First Minister at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.\n\nIt should mean that Mr Swinney is in place to face his inaugural First Minister's Questions session at the Scottish Parliament on Thursday.\n\nMr Swinney has previously faced MSPs at FMQs, having stepped in to cover for Nicola Sturgeon while he was deputy FM, including when she tested positive for Covid-19 back in 2022.\n\nIt is the second time the MSP for Perthshire North has been SNP leader, having led the party between 2000 and 2004.\n\nFollowing his confirmation, Mr Swinney said: \"I am deeply honoured to have been elected as leader of the SNP.\n\n\"I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie warned Mr Swinney his party would oppose any move away from policies introduced as part of the power-sharing Bute House Agreement.\n\nHe said: \"Scotland needs a period of stable government. Mr Swinney knows that if he is to have our support then it must be on the basis of progressive policies that help us to tackle the climate crisis and build a fairer and more equal future.\n\n\"The next Scottish Government will face an important choice. Will they offer a progressive vision for Scotland's future, or will they retreat toward the tepid middle ground, which would force them to rely on the Tories and other pro-union parties?\n\n\"There are a lot of important policies already on their way to delivery as a result of the Bute House Agreement, including better rights for tenants and rent controls, transforming the way we heat our homes and a watertight ban on conversion therapy.\n\n\"We remain utterly committed to these policies and will oppose any move away from them or steps to dilute them.\n\n\"It is also clear that the new Climate Bill must be used to bring about the pace of change that has been lacking since the SNP first started missing climate targets.\"\n\nScottish Tory leader Douglas Ross urged the new SNP leader to drop the party's bid for separation.\n\nAnd he vowed the Tories would \"hold John Swinney to account\" when he \"lets the Scottish people down\".\n\nHe said: \"It's difficult to see how he can be the fresh start Scotland needs, when he's the ultimate continuity candidate.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups.\n\n\"With John Swinney at the helm, the SNP will double down on their independence obsession, the one issue they agree on, and ignore the real priorities of the Scottish people, such as fixing our ailing public services and growing the economy.\"", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9537395", "eventUri": "eng-9537395", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3490196078431373, "wgt": 189, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8112729655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:27:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:27:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:26:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24300249.need-john-swinney-salvage-pro-independence-government/", "title": "We need John Swinney to salvage this pro-independence government", "body": "AFTER all the dust has settled, it seems that through sheer lack of willingness by any other SNP politician, John Swinney will become leader of the SNP and in the process will become First Minister of Scotland.\n\nI'm sure that many within the SNP will be breathing a sigh of relief that there will be a swift and seamless transition of power, with no need for a contest which will reveal any splits within the party.\n\nAt first glance this might seem like a good thing, but will it be viewed like that by many members of the party, and more importantly, the voting public?\n\nGiven that the Sturgeon era was brought to a halt by controversy upon controversy, one might think that a reboot of the party might send out the message that the party leadership wanted to put clear blue water between that old regime and the new one. That they were not to be tainted by events which could soon be revealed in court.\n\nThey have chosen not to do so, and by choosing John Swinney, their seamless transition to fresh government instead becomes a seamless join with a running sore that continues to damage the SNP. From Sturgeon, to Yousaf, to Swinney. As Eric Morecambe used to say: \"You can't see the join!\"\n\nIn depriving the membership of the party a say in selecting who their leader should be, they have continued in the vein of Nicola Sturgeon, centralising decision-making to as few people as possible. Humza Yousaf was to the SNP what Liz Truss was to the Tories, and he has now been replaced by their equivalent of John Major. Swinney is undoubtedly Scotland's dullest and least inspiring politician, and for those of us who remember his last spell as leader, he brings with him an expectation of loss.\n\nREAD MORE: Patrick Harvie speaks out after end of Bute House Agreement\n\nWith an impending Westminster election and a Holyrood election soon after, I can think of no worse choice that the SNP leadership could have imposed on the party. On BBC Debate Night, Neil Gray MSP, campaign manager for Humza Yousaf, said he had endorsed Humza Yousaf because he was the right man for the job, and in his opinion, he had been a good first minister. He then went on to say that in his opinion Swinney was the right man for the job. Fool me twice, shame on me, as they say.\n\nThe whole process in which Humza Yousaf departed office raises more questions than it answers. Surely I can't be alone in thinking that the decision to end the Bute House Agreement with the Greens was not a decision made my Yousaf alone, above the heads of his Cabinet, and without their endorsement?\n\nIf Neil Gray, as he said, worked hard to convince him to stay as first minister, why was he railroaded out by the rest of the Cabinet? One vote from Alba would have saved him and the Scottish Government from the votes of no confidence they faced, yet the SNP made it clear that they would refuse to countenance such an offer. One has to remember that probably 95% of the Alba Party membership are former SNP members, and while they are disappointed in the party's failure to progress independence, they recognise that the SNP are at present still the major party of independence, and as such will support them to achieve that goal.\n\nI find it bizarre that Scotland's second largest independence party's offer of help was rejected outright, in order to cut a backroom deal with the Greens, who the SNP, not Humza Yousaf alone, threw out of government. Clearly there has been a recognition at some level that a continued joint government was not in their interest, and the rejection of Alba over the Greens again indicates no change in direction from the party.\n\nIt's akin to when Marathon rebranded to Snickers. The label changed but the nuts remain.\n\nREAD MORE: SNP activist seeking to challenge John Swinney for party leadership\n\nWhen the Greens asked that Labour withdraw their vote of no confidence it was quite clear to every man and his dog that a deal had been done, and that the Scottish Government was safe. The vote was, by that point, pointless. Knowing that the government was safe, Ash Regan of Alba then knew that she could cast her vote of no confidence without actually ending up being the scapegoat for bringing it down.\n\nUnfortunately, this was manna from heaven for those on the more tinfoil-hatted wing of the SNP, who saw this as evidence that Alba are an MI5 construct, and all the members are secret British Nationalists. These members are, of course, the same folk who used to attend branch meetings and conferences alongside them, and who chapped doors and delivered leaflets in all weathers with them.\n\nA more sensible approach from Regan would have been to abstain, sending the message that she could not endorse them, but ultimately neither would she bring down a Scottish Nationalist government in favour of a British Nationalist one. That opportunity has been lost, and it may now be harder for Alba to reach across to the SNP membership, something that they need to do in the next Holyrood election.\n\nThere is more that unites us than divides us, and as someone who has not forgotten that independence is our ultimate goal, which I want to see sooner, not later, I must ask all our independence supporting politicians to focus on that goal in every act that they do. All our politicians have fallen into the trap of focusing on election cycles, when what we need to do is break the electoral system. We are being told by London that we cannot have a referendum. Good governance brings the confidence to take more responsibility, and we can bypass any referendum by having all independence parties stating, clear and simple, that a vote for them is a vote to declare independence, not to seek permission which will always be refused. It's time to put country before career.\n\nSome people think that a spell out of office is required to refocus, regroup and reorganise. This is akin to football supporters facing relegation, who convince themselves that after a season in the lower leagues, they will come back bigger and stronger. This is seldom the case, and for many teams, that season becomes an extended period in the wilderness. We can only hope that Swinney can salvage something in time for the elections, because the Yes movement cannot afford a loss in any way, shape or form. Relegation is not an option.\n\nJUST as I suspected after the not so secret meeting between John Swinney and Kate Forbes, no sooner had Swinney come out of it than he was stating that yes, he would stand in the \"hardly a race\" to be First Minister.\n\nSoon after, we read of Kate Forbes's agreement with just about everything John Swinney is standing for to become first minister. Now, we read that he has promised Kate a senior role in his government if/when elected.\n\nIt was my guess that this would have happened. Further, it was my reasoning that Forbes would also be promised the deputy first minister job for the interim and until the next Scottish election. Thus giving her the opportunity to become the first minister if the SNP won another term in government.\n\nHowever, John Swinney has not gone that far yet publicly, except to say that a \"senior\" post will be on offer based on her being an \"intelligent, creative, thoughtful person\". Enough said? Quite possibly!\n\nAs stated in my earlier letter, I would like to see Kate Forbes in a senior position whatever that might be, having voted for her in the last first ministerial race subsequent to Nicola Sturgeon's resignation.\n\nThe next two years of Scottish government could be quite interesting. So far as independence is concerned, it looks as if it will be up to us, the sovereign people. A \"people's convention\" would be a good start. The Yes movement doesn't need reinvigorating as suggested by Forbes.\n\nIt is the SNP government that needs invigorating.\n\nFIRSTLY, I would like to wish Humza and his family, which will be increasing in size in due course, all the very best for the future. He always seemed to me to be a thoroughly decent human, being among some other politicians in Holyrood who, in my view, are nothing of the sort! I backed Humza and the Bute House Agreement (BHA) from day one and personally feel so sad about how recent events transpired.\n\nDuring the period after Humza ended the BHA, but before he resigned, I watched an interview Alex Salmond did on the telly. In it, as usual, he slagged off the Greens. Then he said something that nearly made me fall off the sofa. He\n\nsaid Ash Regan was the \"adult in the room\", obviously compared to the Greens and no doubt her detractors within the SNP!\n\nSorry, Alex, you are clearly an intelligent man, but folk with the right type of intelligence - and that is the vital bit - realise that this planet we inhabit is in serious dire straits and urgent, drastic action is required to deal with the crisis. The Greens, not you or Ash, totally get that. In my book, therefore, that easily makes them the real adults in the room!\n\nI read that there was a poll of SNP voters and 60% of them were disappointed by the breakdown of the BHA and I'm definitely one of them. It seemed like anything the Greens proposed to combat climate change while in government was shot down in flames by all and sundry throughout Scotland, except those on the left of the SNP and environmental campaigners.\n\nThey never stood a chance and I definitely don't blame Green politicians or members of their party getting totally frustrated in the end!\n\nI feel this is an opportune time to deal with the elephant in the room. Many, myself included, thought it was a good thing that Humza became the first Muslim and person of colour to become Scotland's First Minister. However, Humza had a hurdle to deal with that none of his predecessors experienced.\n\nThe vehemence some showed towards him right from the off was very suspicious, in my view. I don't doubt for one minute that this was due, in some instances, to sheer racism and/or Islamophobia. I don't believe such sentiment is merely confined to some individuals in Scottish cricket, for example, as has been well publicised over recent years. It's a problem that has never gone away. Just ask those that have been victims of it throughout their lives, including Humza, of course.\n\nOn a lighter note, I know one thing. If the choice for the next leader of the SNP puts a smile on the faces of Alex Salmond, Ash Regan and Fergus Ewing then I'll definitely be greetin'!\n\nLIKE Lesley Riddoch, I am very disappointed that the grassroots who tramp the staircases year in, year out are not getting the chance to hear the candidates' vision for the SNP - but also, and equally important, for Scotland and its people. It's quite obvious a deal has been done and now we'll never know. SHAME.\n\nENGLISH Labour's Viceroy-in-waiting Ian Murray wants an election now. He slams the Scottish administration's record but doesn't say that Scotland not only has the UK's best-performing NHS but has avoided strikes while the English NHS has had almost continual strikes since 2022.\n\nAnd look at Labour-run Wales. The new Welsh Labour leader accepted \u00a3200k from a company owned by a man prosecuted for illegally dumping waste, the Welsh NHS isn't functional according to the Welsh BMA head and 80% of Welsh GPs complain of excessive workloads putting patients at risk. But you won't hear Ian Murray calling for a Welsh election.\n\nThen we have yet another English Labour U-turn, this time a rollback of workers' rights. Starmer says he won't end employers' use of \"fire and rehire\", won't raise sick pay, won't reverse anti-strike legislation and won't ban zero-hours contracts. This makes a complete mockery of English Labour's northern manager Anas Sarwar's promise to \"always be on the side of working people across Scotland.\"\n\nBut we know whose side English Labour is really on - the side of its corporate donors who, the FT reports, are really now \"quite relaxed\" about Labour's plans.\n\nThere's no way English Labour will deliver anything positive for Scotland. There won't be a return to the Single Market and despite saying the union is 'voluntary', Sir Keir says Scotland has no democratic way out and no right to self-determination.\n\nWhat Scotland needs now, Ian, is an end to our nation's exploitation and subjugation by its larger \"partner\".\n\n\"THE governance of any country cannot simply be a revolving door that one party gets to pick time and time again who occupies the highest office in the land.\"\n\nThese were the words of Nicola Sturgeon after the defenestration of Liz Truss by Rishi Sunak. Now that the unimpressive John Swinney is to be the 3rd SNP leader in a year, the charge against them is rank hypocrisy.\n\nThe Swinney Coronation will be viewed (correctly) as yet another stitch-up by the Sturgeon faction. All so the talentless bottom feeders promoted by Sturgeon/Murrell can continue to be paid generous expenses and wages by the public purse.\n\nUnder Sturgeon, the SNP ceased to be a party of independence. She may have said they were pursuing independence, but this was transparent nonsense. Her actions showed she was firmly a closet Unionist.\n\nThese unprincipled grifters sought and got mandates for a referendum in 2016, 2017, 2019, and 2021. During this time, the UK government had to deal with Brexit, Covid-19, and the invasion of Ukraine. The Prime Ministers were Boris Johnson and Liz Truss.\n\nIt is hard to imagine more felicitous circumstances. Yet the unscrupulous charlatan Sturgeon managed to blow it. It was all about her. A personality cult was built up. No opposition was tolerated. The SNP is now paying for the insecurity and imposter syndrome of its ex-leader.\n\nAll that was forthcoming were extremely unpopular lunatic \"gender\" policies that made science denial an actual crime.\n\nWhen Humza Yousaf was elected, I said his record in health, justice, and transport was an indicator he wouldn't last as FM.\n\nThe same will apply to Swinney. His record of failure is even greater than that of the hapless Yousaf.\n\nThe Alba MSP Ash Regan has a bill on the table. This would be for a referendum on the power to hold a referendum. It would be legally tight. The SNP woke faction refused to endorse this reasonable proposal. This yet again exposes them as Devomax fraudsters.\n\nA John Swinney government at Holyrood seals the fate of independence. Nothing will occur for at least a decade, maybe more. This is the legacy of the toxic Sturgeon and her gullible cult. The only way to get independence back on the agenda is to elect actual independence supporters to Holyrood.", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, {"uri": "8114243208", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:55:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24301996.john-swinney-say-independence-snp-leader-launch/", "title": "What John Swinney said about independence in today's big speech", "body": "SCOTTISH independence didn't feature heavily at John Swinney's launch as SNP leader.\n\nIt's not that it wasn't mentioned in his speech at Glasgow University - it was. He said Scotland could \"do more\" with the powers of independence and that he would \"always seek\" to persuade people of that.\n\nDespite that, the topic took a back seat to other issues.\n\n\"If elected first minister, my focus will be the economy, jobs, the cost of living,\" the 60-year-old told attending party members, staff and journalists. \"It will be the NHS, our schools and our public services. It will be addressing the climate crisis,\"\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney backs Humza Yousaf's Scottish independence strategy\n\nBringing an end to his speech, Swinney went on: \"Join me as we open a new chapter. As we create a vibrant economy in every part of our country. As we tackle the challenges faced by the NHS. As we build on the strengths of our schools. As we build more homes. Take climate action. Improve public transport. And create jobs.\"\n\nIn both instances, no mention of independence - which was a stark omission. Instead, the veteran politician particularly highlighted the need for internal party unity and focusing on domestic policy priorities.\n\nOf course, Swinney's focus on unity makes a lot of sense. Nothing can be built on shaky foundations and bringing in a figure with the experience of Swinney should steady the ship.\n\nThe longest-serving deputy first minister the Scottish Parliament has ever seen and a past SNP leader between 2000-2004, \"been there, done that\" springs to mind.\n\nAlready, his move to commit to bringing Kate Forbes more into the fold should go some way in bringing together the left and right of the party. Swinney also said in his speech that he believes the fact he was the only candidate to stand demonstrates the SNP is \"coming back together again\".\n\nWhile the power-sharing agreement with the Greens no longer in place, Swinney will need all that experience as he is forced to lead a minority government at Holyrood.\n\nHe will have to work with other parties in the Scottish Parliament on an issue by issue basis if he wants legislation to be passed by Holyrood.\n\nHe acknowledged as much in his speech.\n\n\"We need to stop shouting at each other and talk,\" he said.\n\nAnd when he first announced he was running for the SNP leadership, Swinney added that his party must now \"work to seek common ground in the Scottish Parliament in the interests of the public and of good governance\".\n\nThat the likes of Scottish Labour and the Scottish Tories will take up that offer of a more civil and collaborative politics rather than attempting to turn the screw - particularly going into a General Election - seems unlikely though, particularly when the former continues to call for an early Holyrood election.\n\nWith the Scottish Greens, they should still find a willing partner on most issues. This is particularly the case on proposed legislation - from the Fair Rents (Scotland) Bill to bans on conversion therapy - which was put forward during their time in government.\n\nTime might be the most pressing issue the new SNP leader is faced with. While a date has yet to have been set, the General Election is approaching with the polls putting Labour and the SNP neck and neck.\n\nSwinney has the tough task to unite his party and place emphasis on the SNP's domestic policy priorities AND work \"very, very hard\" to win back independence supporters. And the latter may prove the most decisive come General Election time.\n\n\"Scotland wins when the SNP wins,\" Swinney said in his speech.\n\nBut the SNP also wins when indy supporters are firmly had, under my leadership, and bluntly, I'd just like to get on with that as quickly as I possible can do, because every day that we spend in an internal contest, which I think we all probably know the outcome of, we delay the possibility for the SNP to start its rebuilding.\"\n\nSwinney told the programme his leadership bid had received \"very, very comprehensive support\", including from former dignity in some acutely difficult circumstances.\n\n\"In particular, his moral leadership on the issue of Gaza has been a light in these dark times.\"\n\nDuring his speech, Mr Swinney also said he was not motivated by personal ambition but that he had stood for leader \"out of a profound sense of duty\" to his party and his country.\n\nHe acknowledged there was \"controversy\" over the fact he was the only candidate for the role, but said this was a sign the SNP was \"coming back together again.\"\n\nHe also pledged to create an \"inclusive and unified team\" and to enable \"open and respectful {"uri": "8114301081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:50:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:50:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:46:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-john-swinney-expected-to-lead-scotland-after-taking-the-helm-of-the-scottish-national-party-5945643.html", "title": "World News | John Swinney Expected to Lead Scotland After Taking the Helm of the Scottish National Party | LatestLY", "body": "London, May 6 (AP) Scotland's former deputy first minister was poised to become its third leader in just over a year after taking the helm of the troubled Scottish National Party on Monday.\n\nJohn Swinney, who led the SNP two decades ago, was the only candidate to replace First Minister Humza Yousaf as the leader of the party.\n\nAlso Read | Hamas Accepts Egyptian-Qatari Ceasefire Proposal for Gaza After Israel Orders Rafah Evacuation Ahead of Attack.\n\nThe SNP has been in turmoil since long-serving First Minister Nicola Sturgeon abruptly stepped down last year during a campaign finance investigation that eventually led to criminal charges against her husband.\n\nSwinney, 60, who joined the party at age 15, will try to bring stability to the SNP as it fights efforts by opponents to weaken it going into UK-wide parliamentary elections expected later this year.\n\nAlso Read | Russia Warns Britain, Plans Nuclear Drills Over West's Possible Deepening Role in Ukraine Amid Rising Tensions.\n\n\"The polarisation of politics does not serve our country well,\" Swinney said as he was named party leader. \"I will reach out to everyone willing to join with us in good faith and seek compromises that serve our nation well. We need to stop shouting at each other and talk. More than that, actually, we need to listen. As first minister, I will do exactly that.\"\n\nYousaf announced his resignation last week after a political miscalculation in which he booted the Green Party from the ruling coalition of Scotland's semiautonomous government. The SNP is one seat short of a majority in the local parliament with 63 of the 128 voting seats, so it needs to partner with at least one opposition party.\n\nThe pro-independence SNP was weakened by the campaign finance scandal and divisions over transgender rights, but was ultimately brought down by Yousaf's decision to oust the Greens because of differences over climate change goals. Yousaf was unable to persuade other parties to back his minority government in Scotland's parliament.\n\nFacing the prospect of two no-confidence votes that had been scheduled, Yousaf quit rather than be forced out.\n\nYousaf will remain first minister until his replacement is elected. Swinney is likely to be elected to that position later this week.\n\nSwinney thanked Yousaf for serving with \"grace and dignity,\" and said that his \"moral leadership on the issue of Gaza has been a light in very dark times.\"\n\nYousaf won a bruising campaign to take over the party after Sturgeon, who was first minister for eight years, resigned unexpectedly in February 2023.\n\nAbout a month later, Sturgeon's husband, Peter Murrell, who was the party's chief executive, was arrested as police investigated how 600,000 pounds ($750,000) earmarked for a Scottish independence campaign was spent.\n\nSturgeon and Colin Beattie, the party's former treasurer, were later arrested and questioned in the inquiry, but they were released without being charged with a crime. Murrell was charged last month with embezzlement.\n\nSwinney had served as Sturgeon's deputy first minister during her tenure as Scotland's leader, but stepped down when she left office.\n\nConservative leader Douglas Ross said that Swinney's past makes him unlikely to bring the change that Scotland needs.\n\n\"John Swinney was joined at the hip with the disgraced Nicola Sturgeon and his fingerprints are all over her numerous policy failures and cover-ups,\" Ross said.\n\nSwinney pledged to lead a center-left government focused on the economy, jobs, the cost of living, the National Health Service, schools, public services and the \"climate crisis.\"\n\nSwinney said that he would make his case to persuade people of the need for Scottish independence, which voters rejected in 2014. He cited Brexit and the cost-of-living crisis, which he blamed on U.K. politicians in London, as being bad for Scotland.\n\n\"They demonstrate why Scotland needs to have independence to make our own decisions and create our best future,\" he said. \"If someone is an independence supporter in Scotland and they want Scotland to be independent, there's only one political party that will ever deliver and that's the Scottish National Party.\"\n\nScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar echoed Ross' remarks, saying that the \"SNP is offering more of the same.\"\n\n\"John Swinney has been at the heart of this incompetent government for 17 years and at the heart of the SNP for 40 years,\" Sarwar said. \"John Swinney's record is one of failure.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/happens-next-john-swinney-115046907.html", "title": "What happens next for John Swinney?", "body": "Becoming the new leader of the SNP does not mean John Swinney will automatically become Scotland's next first minister.\n\nFor that to happen the former deputy first minister has to face a vote in the Scottish Parliament, where he will need to win the support of MSPs.\n\nIt is likely other party leaders could put themselves forward for the ballot, though it is in reality unlikely that they would be successful in this.\n\nHowever for Mr Swinney to win the vote in Holyrood, which could take place as early as Wednesday, he will need some MSPs from opposition parties to either back him in the vote, or at least abstain.\n\nThat is because without the powersharing deal with the Scottish Greens, which was ripped up by Humza Yousaf, the SNP is short of an overall majority in the Scottish Parliament.\n\nThe support of Scottish Greens therefore could still be crucial going forward, in this vote and in others to come at Holyrood.\n\nAssuming he wins the vote, Mr Swinney will then become the Scottish Parliament's nominated candidate to be the country's seventh first minister.\n\nAfter that he would be formally appointed via a royal warrant, a legal document that is authorised by the King.\n\nFollowing that he would officially be sworn into the post in a ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh by the Lord President, Scotland's most senior judge.\n\nThat could happen on Thursday morning with Mr Swinney then potentially going on to take First Minister's Questions for the first time in the new role at noon the same day.\n\nHe will also have to appoint his his ministerial team of cabinet secretaries and junior ministers, with much attention on what position will go to Kate Forbes.\n\nThe former Holyrood finance secretary had been tipped as a possible challenger to Mr Swinney for the SNP leadership, but announced on Thursday she would not stand and would instead back the former deputy first minister in his bid for the top job.\n\nMr Swinney, in announcing his candidacy sought to praise Ms Forbes, who last year ran Mr Yousaf a close second in the contest to succeed Nicola Sturgeon, and giving her a top post in his cabinet team would be seen as a move towards restoring unity within the different {"uri": "2024-05-346047982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:12:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:12:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:15:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/why-the-snp-and-john-swinney-cannot-afford-any-form-of-leadership-contest-scotsman-comment-4617036", "title": "Why the SNP cannot afford any form of leadership contest", "body": "The SNP - and by extension John Swinney - finally have a window of opportunity to try and arrest the party's downward trajectory and regain some momentum.\n\nIn Mr Swinney, the party would have an experienced campaigner at the helm who could draw a line under some of the setbacks that have marred Humza Yousaf's premiership.\n\nAnd the hammering suffered by the Conservative party in the local elections south of the Border has left some clear air for the SNP to sell its political messaging and to attempt to build support behind a 'unity' message.\n\nIt is why the party's hierarchy will be desperately hoping Mr Swinney is the only official bid received when the deadline for SNP leadership nominations closes after 11.59am today.\n\nReports emerged yesterday that long-time party activist Graeme McCormick might be able to raise the 100 signatures required across at least 20 SNP branches to be able to trigger a SNP leadership contest.\n\nMr McCormick is believed to have used the independence march in Glasgow on Saturday, run by All Under One Banner, to drum up support for his candidacy.\n\nIf the activist does manage to achieve the threshold required, no serious analyst would contemplate him being able to legitimately challenge Mr Swinney. But any contest would immediately rob the former deputy first minister of the stable platform required to try and win back the support of disenfranchised SNP voters.\n\nShould Mr McCormick receive the required nominations, a three-week leadership contest would be triggered, with ballots closing on May 27.\n\nThat process would not only delay Mr Swinney's ability to control the narrative in the top job, but it would deliver considerable fodder for opposition parties to throw at the SNP. The financial cost of the contest would also be a major headache.\n\nIt is why the SNP cannot afford anything other than a coronation for Mr Swinney, who will be hoping talk of a leadership contest is {"uri": "8114462135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:20:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:20:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:19:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/europe/2024-05-06-snp-veteran-john-swinney-voted-in-as-scotlands-new-leader/", "title": "SNP veteran John Swinney voted in as Scotland's new leader", "body": "London -- Scottish National Party (SNP) veteran John Swinney was elected as its new leader on Monday and is set to replace Humza Yousaf as Scotland's first minister after he emerged as the sole contender in the contest to pick a new premier.\n\nSwinney's key challenge will be to halt the slide in the SNP's popularity after a string of scandals and political missteps, while keeping alive its ultimate goal of winning independence from the UK.\n\n\"My decision to stand for the leadership is not born out of long-held ambition, but rather a profound sense of duty to my party and to my country,\" Swinney, who joined the party as a teenager in 1979, told a cheering audience in Glasgow.\n\n\"I know there's some controversy that I'm the only candidate to stand for the leadership...For me, the fact that I am the only candidate demonstrates that the Scottish National Party is coming back together again now.\"\n\nYousaf, who had become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation when he was sworn in as first minister in 2023, resigned last week after his decision to end a coalition in the Scottish parliament with the Green Party backfired, triggering a race to determine his successor.\n\nShortly after midday on Monday, the deadline for other contenders to join the contest, the SNP confirmed Swinney as its next leader, ending uncertainty around a possible weeks-long process that would have ensued if there were more candidates.\n\nFormer finance minister Kate Forbes, who narrowly lost a leadership contest to Yousaf when Nicola Sturgeon resigned as leader last year, was expected to run but ruled herself out on Thursday.\n\nForbes had said she and Swinney shared a \"common purpose\".\n\nOver the weekend, there were also reports that party activist Graeme McCormick was hoping to challenge Swinney for the leadership, but Sky News reported late on Sunday that he had decided not to proceed with his nomination, citing a statement from him.\n\nThat left Swinney, who was SNP leader from 2000-2004 and had also served as Scotland's deputy first minister and finance minister, as the sole nominee in the contest.\n\nThe SNP has dominated Scottish politics for 17 years but its popularity has slipped over the past year amid a funding scandal, a series of political blunders, and criticism of how it runs the country. It now heads a minority government in Holyrood.\n\nThe slide has boosted the hopes of Britain's opposition Labour Party of regaining ground in Scotland, one of the UK's four nations, as it seeks to win a British parliamentary election expected later this year.\n\nThe SNP aims to reinvigorate the push for another referendum on independence from the UK.\n\nScots voted against splitting from the UK by 55% against 45% in a referendum in 2014, but the independence movement says Britain's later departure from the EU changed the situation and another referendum is justified -- a claim that both the {"uri": "8113808407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:45:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:45:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:45:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/snp-old-hand-john-swinney-set-to-be-scotlands-new-leader/articleshow/109888675.cms", "title": "SNP old-hand John Swinney set to be Scotland's new leader", "body": "New SNP leader John Swinney aims to unite the party and push for independence despite challenges from within and a resurgent Labour party. He seeks to revitalize the party's fortunes and lead Scotland towards independence.Scotland's likely next leader John Swinney is a political veteran who will have to unify his fractured separatist party and revitalise its flagging independence movement.\n\nThe 60-year-old belongs, named Monday as the new Scottish National Party (SNP) leader, is part of the party's old guard.\n\nHe is also an ally of tarnished ex-first minister Nicola Sturgeon, whom he served as deputy for a record nine years.\n\nSwinney is viewed as a calm head capable of stabilising Scotland's ruling party following 39-year-old Humza Yousaf's turbulent leadership and repairing its broken relationship with former power-sharing partners the Greens.\n\nBut detractors say Swinney -- who has led the party before -- represents more of the same, and is damaged by his defence of former boss Sturgeon, who was arrested in an ongoing party finances scandal.\n\n\"He could hardly be closer to the now discredited Sturgeon leadership so distancing himself from that will be a challenge,\" Edinburgh University politics professor James Mitchell told AFP.\n\n\"(But) Swinney is the ultimate party man, loyal to a fault. He is very well liked in the SNP because of this.\"\n\nBorn in Edinburgh in April 1964, Swinney joined the SNP when he was 15, quickly rising through its ranks and becoming national secretary in the mid-1980s.\n\nHe first became a lawmaker in 1997 when he was elected to the UK parliament in London to represent a constituency in Tayside, in the heart of Scotland.\n\nTwo years later, he was elected to Scotland's regional parliament at Holyrood in Edinburgh when it was re-established after more than 300 years, with Labour at the helm.\n\nSwinney first became SNP leader in September 2000 following the departure of Alex Salmond.\n\nBut he endured a torrid four years in charge as the SNP's fortunes slumped during the early days of Scotland's devolved parliament and the height of New Labour mania under UK prime minister Tony Blair.\n\nDespite an expenses scandal forcing then-Labour first minister Henry McLeish from office in 2001, the opposition SNP still lost several seats at Holyrood in the 2003 Scottish parliamentary election.\n\nSwinney saw off a leadership contest from an SNP activist but was forced to step down after a dismal showing at the 2004 European Parliament elections.\n\n- 'Unite' -\n\nHis political career enjoyed a rebirth in 2007 when the SNP, then under the leadership of Salmond again, became the largest party at Holyrood and Swinney became finance minister.\n\nHe became deputy first minister in 2014 after Sturgeon succeeded Salmond following an independence referendum in which Scotland voted to remain part of the UK.\n\nSwinney occupied several ministerial roles under Sturgeon, including education minister, and gained a reputation for being a steady and trusted hand.\n\nHe faced challenges, though, and twice survived no confidence votes, including over his refusal to publish legal advice during an inquiry into the flawed handling of harassment complaints against Salmond.\n\nAfter Yousaf succeeded Sturgeon in March last year, Swinney stepped down from government, saying it was time for a \"new generation\" to lead.\n\nSince then, internal divisions have been laid bare between progressives pushing trans rights and tough action against climate change, and more conservative members interested in core issues such as the economy.\n\nAll while the SNP faces pressure from a resurgent, union-supporting Labour party that is tipped to form the next UK government following an election due later this year.\n\nSwinney couldn't resist the call by senior SNP figures to return to try to revive his party's fortunes.\n\n\"I want to unite the SNP and unite Scotland for independence,\" he said, launching his leadership bid last week.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24301439.happens-next-snp-leader-john-swinney/", "title": "What happens next for SNP leader John Swinney?", "body": "BECOMING the new leader of the SNP does not mean John Swinney will automatically become Scotland's next first minister.\n\nFor that to happen the former deputy first minister has to face a vote in the Scottish Parliament, where he will need to win the support of MSPs.\n\nIt is likely other party leaders could put themselves forward for the ballot, though it is in reality unlikely that they would be successful in this.\n\nHowever for Swinney to win the vote in Holyrood, which could take place as early as Wednesday, he will need some MSPs from opposition parties to either back him in the vote, or at least abstain.\n\nThat is because without the powersharing deal with the Scottish Greens, which was ripped up by Humza Yousaf, the SNP is short of an overall majority in the Scottish Parliament.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney: I know what it takes to lead minority government and boost independence\n\nThe support of Scottish Greens therefore could still be crucial going forward, in this vote and in others to come at Holyrood.\n\nAssuming he wins the vote, Swinney will then become the Scottish Parliament's nominated candidate to be the country's seventh first minister.\n\nAfter that he would be formally appointed via a royal warrant, a legal document that is authorised by the King.\n\nFollowing that he would officially be sworn into the post in a ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh by the Lord President, Scotland's most senior judge.\n\nThat could happen on Thursday morning with Swinney then potentially going on to take First Minister's Questions for the first time in the new role at noon the same day.\n\nHe will also have to appoint his his ministerial team of cabinet secretaries and junior ministers, with much attention on what position will go to Kate Forbes.\n\nThe former Holyrood finance secretary had been tipped as a possible challenger to Swinney for the SNP leadership, but announced on Thursday she would not stand and would instead back the former deputy first minister in his bid for the top job.\n\nSwinney, in announcing his candidacy sought to praise Forbes, who last year ran Yousaf a close second in the contest to succeed Nicola Sturgeon, and giving her a top post in his cabinet team would be seen as a move towards restoring unity within the different factions of the SNP.\n\nForbes has been out of the Scottish cabinet since have election than John Swinney as FM", "body": "Kate Forbes is first choice with more wanting to go to the polls than see John Swinney take charge\n\nJOHN Swinney is THIRD choice among readers of The Scottish Sun to become the next First Minister.\n\nNicola Sturgeon's former No2 bagged just nine percent of the votes in our online survey into who should be crowned next SNP boss.\n\nMore say they would rather have an election than see him lead the country.\n\nEx-Finance Minister Kate Forbes is the overwhelming favourite among respondents, with nearly 44 percent of ballots -- but says she will not run in the leadership contest.\n\nScottish Labour's Jackie Baillie echoed calls for an election.\n\nShe said: \"That fewer than 10 per cent of readers want the John Swinney coronation that is being foisted upon Scotland says it all about how out of touch the SNP is.\n\n\"The simple fact is that the SNP can change the branding all they want, it is the product that the people of Scotland are now tired of.\n\n\"It's time for change and fresh leadership and only Scottish Labour can deliver it.\"\n\nMore than 1,600 readers shared their views in our online readers' survey.\n\nEducation Secretary Jenny Gilruth languished way back in fourth place with less than one percent of the vote, while health minister Neil Gray was even less popular garnering just a dozen responses.\n\nMr Swinney looks a shoe-in to land the top job after Ms Forbes this week pledged not to take him on.\n\nIt is expected she will land an important role in his first cabinet after offering him her backing.\n\nHe looked set to be ousted after rivals committed to a vote of no confidence in him but jumped before he was pushed.\n\nHis resignation earlier this week triggered a leadership scrap which told the PA news agency that he \"met the thresholds for party rules\", but \"after a lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Mr Swinney he decided to instead give his full support to him.\n\nMr McCormick wrote: \"John and I agreed the challenges which the SNP, our Government and our people face, and explored new thinking on a range of issues which I am confident, as they are advanced, will We should be seeking solutions to problems.\n\n\"I will reach out to everyone willing to join with us in good faith and seek compromises that serve our nation well. We need to stop shouting at each other and talk. More than that, actually, we need to listen. As first minister, I will do exactly that.\"\n\nJohn Swinney paid tribute to his predecessor Humza Yousaf (Andrew Milligan/PA)\n\n- Tributes to predecessor Humza Yousaf\n\nMr Swinney praised the \"grace and dignity\" of his predecessor, and said \"moral leadership on the issue of Gaza has been a light in very dark times\".\n\nHe thanked Mr Yousaf for his contribution to the SNP and for his work as First Minister, and said he expected him to play a part in Scottish politics.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"We must continue to illuminate hope, fight for international justice and be willing to stand up for what we believe to be right. That is what Humza Yousaf did.\n\n\"I know that Humza will continue to make a substantial contribution to the public life of Scotland and I thank him for all that he has done as our party leader and First Minister.\"\n\n- Relations with SNP figures including Kate Forbes\n\nMr Swinney addressed relations with other factions within the SNP and said he had met ex-finance secretary Kate Forbes to discuss her views.\n\nHe thanked Ms Forbes for backing his leadership, and said during a meeting that the former opponents \"came together and discussed the shared ambitions we have for our country and how best to go forward\".\n\nMr Swinney added: \"The simple lesson is that dialogue can bring us to points of agreement and strength.\"\n\nMr Swinney said her and Kate Forbes had discussed their 'shared ambitions\u00b4 (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\n- The Bute House Agreement will not be reinstated\n\nResponding to questions following his speech, Mr Swinney said he will not resurrect the defunct powersharing deal between the SNP and the Scottish Greens, known as the Bute House Agreement.\n\nHe said he would not implement that type of agreement, preferring to take issues on a case-by-case basis.\n\nMr Swinney said: \"I don't intend to return to the Bute House Agreement.\"\n\nMr Swinney and Nicola Sturgeon pose with a Yes sign ahead of the 2014 Scottish independence referendum (Lynne Cameron/PA)\n\n- Scottish independence\n\nMr Swinney said the party would \"get our act together\" and win back disaffected voters.\n\nHe said the \"country could do more if we had the powers of a normal independent nation\", and cited Brexit and the cost-of-living crisis as examples of Westminster decisions \"that are bad for Scotland\".\n\nMr Swinney said: \"They demonstrate why Scotland needs to have independence to make our own decisions and create our best future.\"\n\nTo rapturous applause, he said: \"If someone is an independence supporter in Scotland and they they want Scotland to be independent there's only one political party that will ever deliver and that's the Scottish National Party.\"\n\n- The Cass Review into gender identity services for young people will be 'listened to' amid pledges of a 'rational' approach\n\nMr Swinney described the Cass Review as \"evidence based\", and pledged to listen to clinicians.\n\nHe added: \"The Government will take a rational evidence based approach to the consideration of the Cass Review.\n\n\"On matters of such sensitivity about the wellbeing of children and young people we should listen to clinicians.\"", I have sent out a message which is about unifying the SNP to strengthen our party and win Scottish independence.\n\n\"I think that is necessary as the SNP is not as cohesive today as the party needs to be, and my campaign has attracted very wide support.\n\n\"So I think the SNP has got a chance to start rebuilding from the difficult period that we've had under my leadership and, bluntly, I would just like to get on with that as quickly as I can do because every day that we spend in an internal contest, which I think we all probably know the outcome of, we delay the ability for the SNP to start its rebuilding and I want to get on with that as quickly as I possibly can do.\"\n\nMr Swinney also pointed to the backing he has got from Kate Forbes - the former leadership candidate who lost
