{"uri": "8112871361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:49:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:49:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:40:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13385007/Like-dodgy-old-Nokia-Retro-John-Swinney-unwelcome-relic-past-writes-STEPHEN-DAISLEY.html", "title": "Like a dodgy old Nokia, Swinney is an unwelcome relic from the past", "body": "The early 2000s, I was recently horrified to learn, are now the subject of nostalgia for those born in the 1990s. The Noughties are 'retro' and anything from that period -- Nokia mobiles, iPods, the Xbox -- are considered 'vintage'.\n\nI am placing inverted commas around these terms as a self-defence mechanism. To my ageing mind, the early 2000s were just a few years ago, and they didn't make the best first impression.\n\nThe Noughties were the era of Big Brother, 9/11, dodgy dossiers, Simon Cowell, happy slapping, the Cheeky Girls and, worst of all, someone let Tony Parsons become a novelist.\n\nIt was the worst of times; it was the absolute worst of times.\n\nJohn Swinney says he wants to govern from 'the moderate centre-Left'\n\nIt was the time, and a very unhappy one at that, of John Swinney's first foray into the leadership of the SNP.\n\nSwinney succeeded Alex Salmond in the top job in 2000 and spent the next four years trying and failing to impose discipline on his party.\n\nDepending on who you ask, the hierarchy under Swinney were autocratic control freaks, or the rebels were wreckers and malcontents more interested in factionalism than attaining power.\n\nWherever the truth lies, everyone agrees Swinney was damaged by the loss of eight seats in the 2003 Holyrood election and a failure to gain ground in the following year's European Parliament poll.\n\nCalls to quit grew and he eventually realised the jig was up.\n\nNow he's back and, with Kate Forbes deciding not to contest the leadership this time, looks unlikely to face a serious challenger for the crown.\n\nAfter the calamitous conclusion to Humza Yousaf's ill-starred tenure, it's understandable that SNP members would gravitate to Swinney.\n\nThe party's entry into government in 2007 saw him take up a series of senior Cabinet roles, including deputy first minister, finance secretary and education secretary.\n\nFor 16 of the 17 years the SNP has been in power, Swinney has been around the Cabinet table.\n\nHis achievements are limited. A limp economy during his time at finance, collapsing school performances when he was in charge at education.\n\nBut his appeal to rank-and-file Nationalists is that he weathered one row after another in those portfolios.\n\nThat he did so with bluster and parliamentary invective is irrelevant.\n\nSNP members know they're not electing a man who will turn around the government's fortunes.\n\nThey're putting in a canny bruiser who knows how to handle himself. After the abrupt departures of first Nicola Sturgeon and now Humza Yousaf, the SNP is starting to resemble the UK Tory party with its conveyor belt of hapless leaders.\n\nMembers want stability and they see it in Swinney.\n\nAre they right? Or do they risk repeating their earlier mistake by electing a more experienced Humza Yousaf?\n\nIt is true Swinney is more cautious than the man he is expected to succeed.\n\nHe would not have ended the Bute House Agreement in the peremptory fashion that Yousaf did.\n\nNor would he have allowed his government to drift quite as far to the Left, to the point where it became difficult to distinguish SNP ministers from Green ones.\n\nSwinney is a man of the centre Left, but with more emphasis on the adjective than the noun.\n\nGiven his bitter experience, it is unlikely he would have allowed relations with the backbenches to deteriorate as they did under Yousaf.\n\nBut a less impulsive leadership style aside, it is not at all clear what Swinney brings to the job.\n\nThe parliamentary arithmetic remains the same. The SNP is shy of a majority and will have to convince opposition members if it wants to pass its legislation.\n\nYet with a UK election in the offing and a Holyrood vote only two years away, there will be ever less incentive for the opposition to back SNP budgets and other key bills.\n\nThis may leave Swinney with no choice but to rely on the Greens, and their price is clear.\n\nThey aren't going to vote for a budget that includes funding for fully upgrading the A96.\n\nThey're going to be pushing the government to press ahead with legislation such as a ban on conversion practices, including parents trying to stop their children changing genders.\n\nSwinney says he wants to govern from 'the moderate centre-Left' but as long as he must depend on Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater, his government risks being dragged further leftwards.\n\nUnfortunately for Swinney, it won't be as easy as giving the Greens whatever they want in exchange for his political survival.\n\nThere is a faction of SNP backbenchers who are pro-development and sceptical of radical social policy.\n\nThey spent almost three years longing to get out of the Bute House Agreement and they will not take kindly to it returning as a Bute House Special Handshake.\n\nWith the Greens finally gone, these Nationalists want to keep them gone. And the loss of the government's majority will have emboldened them.\n\nFergus Ewing, Hammer of the Lentil Brigade, has already demanded progress on the A96. The next First Minister cannot take Ewing or any like-minded MSP for granted now.\n\nThen there is the phalanx of progressive Nationalists. They are fully signed up to the radical social agenda and may make their displeasure known if there is any attempt to back away from it\n\nThese are the characters who were preparing to block Kate Forbes at any cost.\n\nThe cost, it turns out, was going back to Swinney.\n\nNow he has to balance all these competing interests, and if there's one thing we know about him, it's that his first shot at leadership was hobbled by his inability to do just that.\n\nWhile juggling all this, he will have to run a government creaking under the pressure of 17 years of policy failure and deteriorating services -- and a voting public that is finally starting to blame the SNP.\n\nIt is a matter of months until that public goes to the polls in what looks set to be the SNP's most bruising encounter with the electorate in some considerable time.\n\nIt could be that Swinney is able to stabilise the party enough to halt further decline but it is not apparent that he has the political charisma to draw back voters already minded to vote Labour.\n\nThe self-created image of Honest John, the boring bank manager, might reassure nervous SNP parliamentarians but Retro John, the blast from the past, is unlikely to excite voters.\n\nNo one looks back fondly on Swinney's first leadership and there is little cause to look forward to his second go.\n\nAlready there are senior Nationalists briefing about plans to replace him with Westminster leader Stephen Flynn after the general election.\n\nNo wonder, when the latest poll has the SNP plummeting to just 15 seats at Westminster and losing the Holyrood election to Labour.\n\nJohn Swinney's second term as SNP leader hasn't even begun and already he's losing two elections and his colleagues are talking about ditching him.\n\nThere are less auspicious circumstances under which to take the helm of a political party, but not many.\n\nSwinney insists he won't be a caretaker and is in it for the long haul. Not only did the attainment gap widen on his watch, he was also responsible for the Covid exam scandal in which the SQA attempted to downgrade the exam results of pupils in the most deprived communities.\n\nAnd of course, he was the Finance Secretary responsible for destroying public finances and laying the groundwork for the current budget blackhole.\n\nFor all the cries that the SNP make of wanting to make Scotland Tory free, the fact is that every budget John Swinney passed from 2007 to 2011 was with Tory support.\n\nThanks to John Swinney, the SNP and the Tories cut local services and centralised power for four years.\n\nLet's be clear - John Swinney has been brought in to try and manage his chaotic and divided party - not to focus on running our country.\n\nThe return of John Swinney is the result of the SNP putting their own party's survival before the national interest.\n\nParty before country, spin before facts - this is all the SNP has to offer.\n\nFor all his claim that he is not a caretaker leader, this is just the start of the longest SNP leadership contest in history.\n\nDon't take my word for it - climate secretary Mairi McAllan said Swinney is the right man 'for the moment.'\n\nBoth John Swinney and the entire SNP's record is mired in chaos and failure - so it's no wonder they are running scared from an election.\n\nIt's hard to escape a sense of de ja vu watching a deeply chaotic and hopelessly divided government impose its second unelected leader in a row on our country.\n\nIn 2022 the Tories reduced the office of Prime Minister to a game of musical chairs, giving us Boris Johnson, Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak in under a year.\n\nThe SNP were rightly scathing of this farce at the time, with then-leader Nicola Sturgeon describing it as \"preposterous, democratically\".\n\nAnd yet here we are, watching the SNP lift directly from the Tory playbook and install a revolving door at Bute House.\n\nHumza Yousaf was in the job for just over a year when he took a wrecking ball to his own government - but this is not just about one man's incompetence.\n\nThe chaos engulfing this SNP government has been 17 years in the making.\n\nFor 17 years, the SNP has mismanaged lifeline services and squandered Scotland's potential.\n\nEvery single institution in our country has been left weaker by this government.\n\nThere are over 800,000 people stuck on NHS waiting lists and almost 10,000 children living in temporary accommodation.\n\nIn schools, violence is rising and standards are falling, while police officer numbers are being cut and crimes are being given a free pass.\n\nOur economy is flatlining and millions of pounds are being wasted on failed projects.\n\nThis is a party that has lost its way and a government that has lost touch, and swapping around the person at the top for the second time in 14 months won't fix that.\n\nThat is particularly true when the SNP's answer to their current woes is also the architect of them.\n\nWhile the SNP is once again putting its own party interests ahead of Scotland's national interest, Scottish Labour is ready to deliver the change our country needs.\n\nIt used to be the SNP who relished elections while Scottish Labour feared them - but now the opposite is true.\n\nScottish Labour has a plan to rebuild our struggling NHS, revive our flatlining economy and put optimism and hope back in Scottish politics.\n\nAcross the UK, we are ready to boot out this disastrous Tory government and improve lives here in Scotland by making work pay and cutting energy bills.\n\nIt's time for change - and the sooner Scottish voters get a say the better.\n\nBring on a U.K. and a Scottish election.\n\nTo sign up to the Daily Record Politics newsletter, clickhere", "source": {"uri": backs out of leadership race and gives full support to John Swinney", "body": "SNP activist Graeme McCormick has ended his bid to become the next leader of the party and has given his full support to John Swinney, who is now the only official candidate.\n\nMr McCormick, who had made a last-minute bid for the leadership, said he would \"not proceed\" with his nomination and would instead support Mr Swinney, meaning the Perthshire North MSP is the likely candidate to replace Humza Yousaf in the top job and is set to become the next first minister of Scotland.\n\nMr McCormick told the PA news agency that he \"met the thresholds for party rules\", but \"after a lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Mr Swinney he decided to instead give his full support to him.\n\n\"This is a fresh start for our members and our politicians, and I'm sure that John's determination to deliver independence will be rewarded at the forthcoming general election.\n\n\"I have therefore concluded that I shall not proceed with my nomination for party leader but instead support John Swinney's nomination for party leader and first minister of Scotland.\"\n\nMr McCormick had told journalists at the weekend that he expected to secure the 100 nominations needed from 20 branches, but this had yet to be officially confirmed.\n\nMr Swinney, who described himself as the candidate to unite the party after a \"difficult\" few years, said an election contest would delay the SNP's essential rebuild.\n\nBut he signalled he would win any potential contest, telling Sky News that party members \"probably know "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24301965.unopposed-snp-leadership-contest-stops-opposition-gloating/", "title": "Wee Ginger Dug: Unopposed SNP leadership contest stops opposition from gloating", "body": "John Swinney at Glasgow University giving his acceptance speech as leader of the SNP (Image: PA)\n\nJohn Swinney has become leader of the SNP and is set to become the next first minister after nominations closed at noon today and he was the only candidate.\n\nThe other names mentioned as possible candidates, former finance secretary Kate Forbes and party stalwart Graeme McCormick, both dropped out of the race after meeting with the former deputy first minister.\n\nThey both announced they had productive meetings with him and were withdrawing their candidacies and giving Swinney their full support.\n\nThere was a widespread feeling within the party that following weeks of upset and trauma, the very last thing the party needed right now was the expense and uncertainty of a three-weeklong leadership contest.\n\nREAD MORE: What happens next for SNP leader John Swinney?\n\nIt would have given Scotland's anti-independence media no shortage of negative SNP on SNP sound bites to headline and publicise, a prospect which was being eagerly anticipated on social media by anti-independence politicians.\n\nOver the weekend, BBC Scotland had been excitedly talking up the possibility of a leadership contest, and when it became clear that there wasn't going to be one you could hear the wails of disappointment from Pacific Quay.\n\nYou could hear them all the way over in the offices of Labour's Scottish accounting unit in John Smith House in West Regent Street, where they'd be drowned out by the wails of disappointment originating from within the building.\n\nAfter he was confirmed as the new leader of the SNP, Swinney wrote on social media that he was \"honoured to have been elected\".\n\nJohn Swinney gave his acceptance speech at Glasgow University\n\nHe could become first minister as early as tomorrow after out-going first minister Humza Yousaf holds his final Scottish Government cabinet meeting and officially tenders his resignation to King Charles.\n\nMSPs will then be given the opportunity to vote on the new first minister and if the Scottish Greens vote alongside the SNP the result is a foregone conclusion.\n\nHowever, the debate will of course provide Anas Sarwar and Douglas Ross the opportunity for grandstanding and for demanding the immediate elections that neither called for when Mark Drakeford, the first minister of Wales, stood down or at any point during the revolving door leadership changes in the Tory party.\n\nIt is not absolutely certain that the Scottish Greens will vote with the SNP or abstain.\n\nHowever, they have signalled their openness to discussions with Green co-convenor Patrick Harvie, saying in a statement: \"Scottish Green MSPs will meet to discuss our approach to the votes taking place this week.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney: SNP must work ' very hard' to win back independence supporters\n\nWe are committed to delivering on our vision of a fairer, greener, and more equal Scotland, and are open to talks with John Swinney and his team about how we can work together to make that happen.\"\n\nFollowing his successful election by MSPs, the new first minister will then have to swear three oaths of office at the Court of Session in Edinburgh before officially taking office.\n\nFor his part Scottish Tory leader, who got his own job as a consequence of an internal party putsch which unseated the previous leader Jackson Carlaw who had been democratically elected by the Scottish Tories' dwindling and elderly membership, passive-aggressively congratulated Swinney on becoming SNP leader \"for a second time\".\n\nCarlaw then immediately demanded that he abandon \"his relentless push for independence.\" Then without a scintilla of self-awareness, he criticised the SNP for engineering a \"stitch-up\" to \"ensure Swinney's coronation.\"\n\nScottish Tory leader Douglas Ross at FMQ's\n\nHave a wee look in the mirror Ross son, is that not the ghost of Carlaw looming over your shoulder?\n\nIn other news, it looks as though a leadership challenge to Rishi Sunak will not come to pass despite his party's dire showing in last week's local and mayoral elections in England as well as a Westminster by-election in Blackpool South - the results have been described as the party's worst performance in 40 years.\n\nThe Tories have belatedly realised that a change of leader won't do anything to improve their dismal electoral prospects and potential leadership hopefuls are going to sit back and let Rishi Sunak be the fall guy for deep-rooted Tory problems which, to be fair, are not entirely of his own making - although he certainly bears a not inconsiderable share of the blame.\n\nPlenty of influential voices in the party want the Tories to pivot even further to the right because apparently the party's real problem is that it's not nasty enough and is not completely unmoored from reality.\n\nThe fact that one of those influential voices is Liz Truss tells you all you need to know about how deranged the modern Conservative party has become.\n\nIf Truss was a doctor she'd have been struck off, but the Tories still think that there is value in her patient slaughtering snake oil.\n\nIn the aftermath of the election results, Suella Braverman, another cruel and incompetent right-wing Tory with her eye on the leadership who would never rise above the back benches in any party which still maintained a tenuous grasp on self-awareness, took to the BBC to insist that a change of leadership would not turn her party's fortunes around, and demanded that Sunak must own the Conservatives' failures.\n\nSunak's grasp on the leadership is really - and paradoxically - being protected by just how dreadful things are for the Tories right now.\n\nThere are plenty of vultures circling, not the least of which is Braverman, but none of them want to make a move until after Sunak carries the can for the inevitable drubbing that the Tories are set to take at the Westminster general election expected later this year.\n\nSunak will stagger on for the time being, unloved by his own party, but safe in his job for {"uri": "8111476864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "19:05:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T19:05:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T19:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.chelmsfordweeklynews.co.uk/news/national/24299770.snp-retain-just-15-43-seats-labour-set-overtake-scotland-poll/", "title": "SNP to retain just 15 of 43 seats with Labour set to overtake in Scotland: poll", "body": "The SNP will retain just 15 of its current 43 seats at the forthcoming general election, according to a new poll for the Sunday Times.\n\nThe forecast comes as Humza Yousaf announced his resignation as First Minister on Monday after he abruptly ended the Bute House Agreement with the Scottish Green Party.\n\nThe Sunday Times poll, by Norstat - formerly known as Panelbase, is one of the first of its kind since Mr Yousaf announced his resignation, and looked at voting intentions for both Westminster and Holyrood.\n\nIt found that while support for independence remains largely unchanged, Labour is set to overtake the SNP at both Westminster and Holyrood, bringing an end to the SNP's streak of four consecutive election victories.\n\nThe survey comes as John Swinney is now expected to become first minister on Tuesday, provided no other challengers enter the race.\n\nWhen asked who would make the best first minister from a list of SNP candidates, Mr Swinney and Kate Forbes were neck and neck with the public on 23%, although Ms Forbes has said she will not be standing.\n\nStephen Flynn, the SNP leader at Westminster, was backed by 7%, and Jenny Gilruth, the Scottish education secretary, scored just 2%.\n\nThe SNP vote share in a Westminster election would fall to its lowest level since the 2014 independence referendum, the poll says.\n\nThe party would hold just 15 of its 43 seats with Scottish Labour winning 28 - a dramatic increase from its current two.\n\nAccording to the Sunday Times poll, the SNP would attract votes from 29% of the electorate - a fall of three points in a month, while Labour's share increased by two points to 34%.\n\nThis would return 15 SNP MPs and amount to a significant reversal in electoral performance.\n\nUnder Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP became the third largest party at Westminster, winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats in 2015.\n\nThere are currently 43 SNP MPs at Westminster.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives, whose vote share remained at 16% in the poll, would add three seats to return nine MPs - while the Liberal Democrats, on 8%, would boost their yield by one to five MPs.\n\nSupport for independence remains evenly balanced, with 48% in favour of Scotland leaving the UK and 52% backing the Union.\n\nVoting intentions at Holyrood show the SNP remains a point ahead of Labour in the constituency vote at 34%.\n\nThe Conservatives would pick up 14% of the vote, the Lib Dems 9% and the Greens 5% - with the remaining 5% to other parties.\n\nBut Scottish Labour has edged a point ahead of the SNP on the more proportional regional list vote with the nationalists' return of 27%.\n\nThe Tories would win 17% of regional votes, the Greens 9%, Lib Dems 8%, Reform UK 6% and Alex Salmond's Alba Party 4%.\n\nAn analysis by polling expert Sir John Curtice for the Sunday Times found that this result would leave Labour as the largest party at Holyrood with 40 seats.\n\nThe remainder of the chamber would be 38 for the SNP, 24 Conservatives, 10 Greens, nine Lib Dems and eight Reform parliamentarians.\n\nThis would mark a historic breakthrough for Nigel Farage's party in Scotland as it at least partially replicates its gains in England by attracting some older, Brexit-supporting Tories north of the border.\n\nSir John, professor of politics at Strathclyde University - who compiled the seat projections, said the \"question that now arises is whether the coronation of John Swinney will enable the SNP to turn the page\".\n\nHe added: \"Even among those who said they would vote Yes in another independence referendum, only 56% said they were now willing to back the SNP for Westminster, as would only two-thirds who voted for the party in 2019.\"\n\nNorstat interviewed 1,086 people aged 16 or over in Scotland between April 30 and May 3.\n\nSNP depute leader Keith Brown commented: \"After 14 years of cruel Tory governments inflicting endless damage on Scotland and Keir Starmer's Labour offering no meaningful alternative, it's clear only the SNP and independence offers a better future for our country.\n\n\"The SNP is the only party standing up for the priorities of people across Scotland and offering a positive vision for the future where decisions about Scotland are made in Scotland.\n\n\"At the general election Scottish voters have the chance to reject the cosy status quo of a broken Westminster system that is failing them and vote to elect SNP MPs who will always stand up for their interests\".", "source": {"uri": We will work day and night to earn your trust and deliver the change Scotland needs.\"\n\nThe poll says the SNP would attract votes from 29 per cent of the electorate while Labour's share increased by two points to 34 per cent.\n\nThis would return 15 SNP MPs and amount to party's poorest performance since 2010. The party won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in 2015 and there are currently 43 SNP MPs.\n\nThe Scottish Conservatives would add three seats to return nine MPs while the Liberal Democrats, on 8 per cent, would increase their seats by one to five MPs.\n\nSupport for independence remains balanced, with 48 per cent in favour.\n\nVoting intentions at Holyrood show the SNP at 34 per cent, remaining a point ahead of Labour in constituencies.\n\nThe Conservatives would pick up 14 per cent of the vote, the Lib Dems 9 per cent, Greens 5 per cent and the remaining 5 per cent going to other parties.\n\nOn the regional list vote, Scottish Labour has edged a point ahead of the 27 per cent who support the SNP.\n\nThe Tories would win 17 per cent of regional votes, the Greens 9 per cent, Lib Dems 8 per cent, Reform UK 6 per cent and Alba 4 per cent.\n\nPolling expert and professor of politics at Strathclyde University Sir John Curtice, said the \"question that now arises is whether the coronation of John Swinney will enable the SNP to turn the page\".\n\nForty-two per cent say an election should take place once Yousaf is replaced.\n\nAsked who would make the best first minister, Swinney and Forbes John Swinney is poised to become Scotland's first minister this week with nominations closing at midday for leader of the Scottish National party without a challenger expected to come forward.\n\nSwinney, who led the party in the early 2000s, is expected to face a vote in parliament as early as Tuesday as he seeks to reunite the SNP and face off a rising challenge from Scottish Labour in the upcoming general election.\n\nHis pathway to the party leadership had faced a potential delay when SNP activist Graeme McCormick began gathering nominations for a challenge that would have triggered a leadership contest.\n\nMcCormick on Sunday withdrew from the contest after a \"lengthy and fruitful conversation\" with Sweeney in which they agreed on the \"challenges\" facing the SNP and Scotland and also \"explored new thinking on a range of issues\".\n\nKate Forbes, who was beaten by Humza Yousaf in last year's leadership contest, stepped aside last week after Swinney offered her a \"significant\" role in government.\n\nWith the SNP slightly short of a majority with 63 seats, compared with 65 for the opposition, Swinney would need to secure votes or abstentions from outside his party if he ran for first minister unopposed.\n\nIf other parties nominate any challengers, Swinney would only need to secure more votes than his competitors.\n\nHis proposed cabinet is expected to follow with parliament voting to approve their nominations as early as Thursday.\n\nThe Scottish Greens, whose group of seven MSPs have taken on a pivotal role in Scottish politics, are {"uri": "8110663235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "05:44:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T05:44:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T05:43:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24298824.john-swinney-cabinet-reshuffle-reset-ahead/", "title": "John Swinney: Cabinet reshuffle and government reset: What's happening next week", "body": "Nominations in the contest close at noon on Monday and barring no surprises from any wildcat candidate the veteran parliamentarian the Perthshire North MSP is expected to be confirmed as party leader shortly after midday.\n\nHe could then be formally elected by parliament as First Minister on Tuesday and sworn in as the seventh First Minister of Scotland on Wednesday.\n\nThe latter will involve a short ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh where he will take the oath of office, known as an \"official declaration\", and pledge allegiance to the King.\n\nREAD MORE: Mairi McAllan: SNP did not want another 'bruising' contest\n\nMr Swinney could also unveil his new cabinet on Wednesday and like Humza Yousaf, face his inaugural First Minister's Questions (as First Minister) on the Thursday.\n\nOne of Mr Swinney's main messages in his speech to supporters when he launched his campaign at the Grassmarket Community Project in Edinburgh on Thursday was the need to unify the party - admitting it was polarised.\n\n\"I have to accept that my party is not as cohesive as it needs to be. This has to change,\" he said in his speech on Thursday morning.\n\nSNP MSP Kate Forbes pictured during her party's leadership contest last year. Photo Colin Mearns.\n\n\"Just as we must fight against the polarisation of our politics, we cannot allow the SNP to be polarised.\"\n\nHe heaped praise on former finance secretary Kate Forbes saying if he became First Minister she would have a \"significant role\" in government.\n\n\"We have many talented people leading the work of the Scottish Government. I want Kate Forbes to play a significant part in that team. She is an intelligent, creative and thoughtful person, who has much to contribute to our national life. And if I am elected, I will make sure that Kate is able to make that contribution,\" he said.\n\nMr Swinney declined to say if Ms Forbes would be given the role of his deputy when questioned by reporters after his speech.\n\nThat is certainly the expectation among some. However, it would mean a demotion for Shona Robison, who was Humza Yousaf's deputy and also finance secretary in Mr Yousaf's government.\n\nIt will also be interesting to see if Mr Swinney makes any other changes to his top team. For instance, will Neil Gray, Jenny Gilruth and Mairi McAllan remain in their respective roles as health, education and net zero secretaries?\n\nAnd in terms of other ministerial appointments, will allies of Ms Forbes such as former business minister Ivan McKee and her former campaign manager Michelle Thomson, be handed roles in government in a further move to unify the party and heal divisions?\n\nMr Swinney also underlined in his speech that there would be a shift of focus of his administration onto growing the economy to fund and deliver public services and fight child poverty.\n\nHow will that ambition be reflected in the new cabinet and ministerial team? Will policy areas be reviewed perhaps to give more weight to the needs of business and economic growth?\n\nA further issue to watch out for will be whether there will be less government focus given to policies around transgender rights.\n\nThe policy was given a significant focus under both Nicola Sturgeon and Humza Yousaf but has been hugely difficult for the SNP in regards party unity.\n\nThe gender recognition reform bill - blocked in the end by the UK Government - saw a large revolt of SNP MSPs in 2022 over plans to make it easier for transgender people to legally change their gender through a process of self-declaration.\n\nIt was telling, that when asked by a reporter on Thursday to say whether a transgender woman was a woman, Mr Swinney was keen to moved the question on.\n\nHe responded: \"If our politics is defined purely and simply by these questions, I think we're not addressing the core issues and challenges that people face in our society. So, today, I am going to address the core challenges and priorities that face people in our society.\"\n\nDoes such a shift of direction onto bread and butter issues mean less of a focus on the debate over transgender rights?\n\nIf so, will prominent advocates of gender self-identification such as equalities minister Emma Roddick remain in her role or be moved to another portfolio or out of government altogether?\n\nAnd longer term, what will happen to plans to ban conversion therapy, a commitment to the Greens in the now defunct Bute House Agreement?\n\nShould Mr Swinney press ahead with such plans he is likely to meet opposition from some in his party. But if he does not, others in his party could be unhappy.\n\nOver the coming months, as a general election looms, and then a Holyrood election is held in 2026, the new First Minister will have to unite his party, keep it united, and drive the key legislation of his minority government - reforms he wants to see tackle the core issues of economic growth and social justice - through parliament.\n\nMr Swinney will require all his experience and political skills to steer a steady course.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald"}, {"uri": "2024-05-346636312", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:56:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:56:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:35:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/06/john-swinney-expected-to-lead-scotland-after-being-confirmed-as-scottish-national-party-leader/", "title": "John Swinney expected to lead Scotland after being confirmed as Scottish National Party leader", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Scotland's former deputy first minister, John Swinney, was confirmed Monday as head of the Scottish National Party and is expected to become the country's next leader, its third in just over a year.\n\nSwinney, who led the SNP two decades ago, was the only candidate to replace First Minister Humza Yousaf as the leader of the party that has been in turmoil since long-serving First Minister Nicola Sturgeon abruptly stepped down last year during a campaign finance investigation that eventually led to criminal charges against her husband.\n\n\"I am deeply honored to have been elected as leader of @theSNP,\" Swinney said on social media platform X. \"I will give all that I have to serve my party and my country.\"\n\nYousaf announced his resignation last week after a political miscalculation in which he booted the Green Party from his coalition government. The SNP is one seat short of a majority in the local parliament with 63 of the 128 voting seats, so it needs to partner with at least one opposition party.\n\nSwinney, 60, who joined the party at age 15, will try to bring stability to the SNP as it fights efforts by its foes to weaken it going into U.K.-wide parliamentary elections expected later this year.\n\nThe Labour Party launched a no-confidence motion against Yousaf that failed last week after he said he would step down.\n\nThe pro-independence SNP was weakened by the campaign finance scandal and divisions over transgender rights, but was ultimately brought down by Yousaf's decision to oust the Greens because of differences over climate change goals. Yousaf was unable to persuade other parties to back his minority government in Scotland's parliament.\n\nFacing the prospect of two no-confidence votes that had been scheduled, Yousaf quit rather than be forced out.\n\nHe will remain first minister until his replacement is elected. I will give all that I have to serve my Party and my Country,\u201d Swinney, who joined the party as a teenager in 1979, said on social media.\n\nHe is expected to give a speech later in the day.\n\nYousaf, who had become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation in March 2023, resigned last week after his decision to end a coalition with the Green Party backfired, triggering a contest to pick his replacement.\n\nShortly after midday on Monday, the deadline for other contenders to join the race, the SNP confirmed Swinney as the new leader, ending uncertainty around a possible weeks-long process that would have ensued if there were more candidates.\n\nFormer finance minister Kate Forbes, who narrowly lost a leadership contest to Yousaf when Nicola Sturgeon resigned as leader, was expected to challenge Swinney for the premiership, but ruled herself out on Thursday. Forbes had said she and Swinney shared a \u201ccommon purpose\u201d.\n\nOver the weekend, there were also reports that party activist Graeme McCormick was hoping to challenge Swinney for the SNP would delay rebuild, says Swinney", "body": "John Swinney has argued a divisive SNP leadership contest could delay the party's essential \"rebuild\" amid reports a veteran activist could enter the race to replace Humza Yousaf.\n\nThe former deputy first minister could become SNP leader from Monday afternoon if he runs unopposed, with Mr Swinney stating he would like to get on with that job \"as quickly as possible\".\n\nHowever, reports suggest a leadership battle may be on the cards after activist Graeme McCormick used the independence march in Glasgow to drum up support for his candidacy.\n\nIt is understood Mr McCormick believes he is very likely to receive the 100 nominations from at least 20 SNP branches before the Monday deadline.\n\nMr McCormick has previously been critical of the SNP-led Scottish Government, using last year's party conference to criticise its independence strategy.\n\nIf he won the leadership race against Mr Swinney, he would not be able to become first minister as he is not elected in the Scottish Parliament, with Mr McCormick reportedly telling members he believes the roles should be run by two different individuals.\n\nBut, Mr Swinney, who at this point remains the only confirmed candidate, told the Sky News programme Sunday Morning with Trevor Phillips he felt an internal contest would hamper the SNP's ability to recover from its turbulent period quickly.\n\nHe said: \"I think the SNP has got a chance to start rebuilding from the difficult period that we have had, under my leadership, and bluntly, I'd just like to get on with that as quickly as I possible can do, because every day that we spend in an internal contest, which I think we all probably know the outcome of, we delay the possibility for the SNP to start its rebuilding.\"\n\nMr Swinney told the programme his leadership bid had received \"very, very comprehensive support\", including from former finance secretary Kate Forbes, who earlier ruled herself out of the contest.\n\nShould Mr McCormick receive the required nominations, a three-week leadership contest will be triggered, with ballots opening on Monday May 13 and closing on May 27.\n\nBut if Mr Swinney runs unopposed, he will be the next SNP leader and he will likely become first minister as early as next week after a Holyrood vote.\n\nMr Swinney, who previously led his party from 2000 to {"uri": "8110663228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "05:45:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T05:45:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T05:43:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/24298658.going-save-scotland-certainly-wont-swinney/", "title": "Letters: Who is going to save Scotland? It certainly won't be John Swinney", "body": "Ms Marr was effusive in backing Michael Matheson as an honest politician yet he tried to defraud Scotland of \u00a311,000 before blaming it upon his own family. He was found to have broken the ministerial code and we still await news of the sanctions to be applied.\n\nShe called Humza Yousaf a competent First Minister yet he had to resign after he admitted his own catastrophic failure.\n\nShe hails Kate Forbes' decision to stand aside. Really? It appears that Ms Forbes was taken behind closed doors and the old guard's intentions made very clear to her.\n\nNow she lauds John Swinney as the new leader of the SNP who will miraculously cure all the SNP's ills and woes. She seems to have forgotten the failure in court of his Named Persons Bill and the absolute slating it received from the judiciary who likened it to the act of a dictatorship. As Education Secretary he took us out of PISA and other standards because they confirmed his disastrous tenure. Just to cap it all, he is the next continuity candidate of the discredited Sturgeon era - although in his defence it shall be hard to find out his record in that era due to the number of records that were deleted or never recorded in the first place.\n\nAs a professional seaman, there is one thing that makes me react spontaneously to help someone in peril no matter the situation: that is hearing Mayday! Mayday! Mayday! That is what went through my mind when I listened to John Swinney as he announced his intention to run for the post of First Minister on May Day. There was added irony in The Herald reporting seven ferries out of action (\"CalMac chaos escalates further\", The Herald, May 1) that actually became nine when the Isle of Cumbrae sitting in for Loch Shira on the Cumbrae service broke down and was withdrawn and the Loch Dunvegan on the Colintraive service having to implement a reverse-on drive-off service due to problems with her forward ramp and no backup vessel being available. Mr Swinney tells us that transport will be a priority in his First Minister role, when will he give us a fully financed plan to replace our ageing ferry fleet and end the unworkable CMAL/CalMac arrangement?\n\nSo just who is going to save Scotland? It won't be Mr Swinney. Just like CalMac, the SNP has run out of lifeboats to launch and deck chairs to rearrange.\n\nWHILE I would prefer Kate Forbes to be Scotland's First Minister, the deliberations over the last few days about who would be more suitable have brought out quite a lot of vitriol towards both contenders.\n\nNone of us are the same people we were 20 years ago and while Professor Sir John Curtice may have been right to say that John Swinney \"wasn't really that good at it\" first time round as leader (\"Curtice says Swinney should make Flynn his running mate in SNP leadership contest\", The Herald, April 30), if people are judged forever on their unwise decisions they made 20 years ago it is a very sad state. It seems no one must ever be allowed to forget their past. This reflects a very unforgiving society, as is demonstrated by the hounding of people of influence who once made a foolish statement on social media when they were teenage and continue to be vilified for their immaturity.\n\nMr Swinney talked about respect on Radio Scotland and commented that First Minister's Questions had been anything but respectful. Hopefully he can encourage more respect and kindness across the parties if he does become First Minister next week.\n\nIrene Munro, Conon Bridge.\n\n* SURELY everyone knows why Kate Forbes decided not to stand for the position of leader of the SNP. Once again she has proved how astute she is by holding back at this time.\n\nMild-mannered John Swinney will lead the party to a humiliating defeat at the next election and will be forced to resign. Ms Forbes will then step into the breach to take control of the SNP for the next five years.\n\nAlan McGibbon, Paisley.\n\n* PASS the sick bag. I find all the recent drivel being spoken about what's best for the people, the country and so on a bit nauseating and disingenuous. We can all see through this charade and know perfectly well it is nothing to do with these lofty aims. It's about how can a politician maintain his/her/etc snout in the trough for as long as possible.\n\nBRIAN Wilson hasn't held back in his views (\"Swinney as FM? That would be a democratic outrage\", The Herald, May 2).\n\nI will leave to one side all that Mr Wilson has to say about John Swinney's record because it is not relevant to Mr Wilson's ultimate point, which is that \"the case for a Holyrood election is unanswerable\". However, the fact is that the UK and devolved Scotland are representative parliamentary democracies, not presidential systems.\n\nHowever much any of us might not like it there is nothing constitutionally, or even democratically, under the existing system wrong with Liz Truss and then Rishi Sunak succeeding Boris Johnson. The same applies to the succession of Nicola Sturgeon by Humza Yousaf and now Mr Swinney. Under our system, candidates for Prime Minister and First Minister are nominated by their party and appointed by a majority of elected representatives in parliament.\n\nWhere many might agree that Mr Wilson has a point lies rather in the politics of this rather than in the parliamentary system. Both Mr Sunak (definitely) and Mr Swinney (most likely), and their parties, will have their meeting with electoral accountability, which is as it should be. If there is any \"outrage\" it would be better directed at the political system itself, preferably with a proposed, and better, alternative arrangement.\n\nWe can now, perhaps, expect complaints about a \"coronation\" rather than a leadership contest. I suspect though, that in the event of a contest, those same people would be trying to make political capital from it with claims of a party riven by division and wasting time and energy that would be much better spent governing. But that's partisan politics for you.\n\nI am confident that Mr Wilson would not dream of contributing to your pages in such a vein.\n\nREAD MORE: Hard luck, unionists: SNP will be more united than ever\n\nREAD MORE: SNP's big problem is it won't accept the world has left it behind\n\nREAD MORE: Humza Yousaf was set up to fail by Nicola Sturgeon\n\nSo who controls Scottish Labour?\n\nI HAVE to say that I am shaking my head in disbelief. First we had Rachel Reeves demanding (yes, demanding) that all MSPs vote to try and bring down the Scottish Government. Now I have to ask: why does an Opposition MP in London believe that they are in a position to demand anything from democratically elected representatives of the voters in Scotland?\n\nAs if that wasn't enough, guess what happened next? There was a vote in Holyrood to give the Waspi (Women Against State Pension Inequality) women the compensation they are entitled to. I would have expected Labour to support this and vote for it, but no, they abstained! Why? Instructions from London again?\n\nIt has to be one of two things. Either Labour in Scotland doesn't think that these women deserve the compensation they are entitled to or they have been told by Keir Starmer to abstain and obeyed. Which is it?\n\nI have to wonder, who does Labour in Scotland answer to? Is it the people of Scotland or their bosses in London?\n\nAS the conflict in Gaza continues and Western leaders refuse to restrain Benjamin Netanyahu and his cabinet from their savagery, I find my \"bleeding heart\" (which I thought had became cauterised and inured to the relentless suffering of the Palestinian people because it is just not possible to walk around with that level of grief), I am once again consumed with sadness and rage.\n\nA Palestinian surgeon, Adnan Al-Bursh, who trained at King's College London, has been tortured to death in an Israeli prison. Just weeks ago another surgeon had been shot in his own operating theatre after refusing to leave a patient lying open on the table, imprisoned for 45 days without medical care, had his right eye poked out with a rifle butt and then dumped near the Gaza border where he had to crawl for two hours before seeking help. Why are the medical professional bodies not speaking out in solidarity with the hundreds of their colleagues being treated like this?\n\nBritish politicians with the honourable exception of the departing First Minister have abjectly and cravenly colluded in this utterly monstrous evil. But a spark of hope, not seen since the days of my childhood during Vietnam and the civil rights movement, has lit up the world. The students protesting are the conscience of the world. Confronting police brutality, hired thugs beating them with baseball bats and the threat to graduating or future employment have not deterred them. They are heroic, and whether the UK media reports it fairly or not we know the truth and we know that history is on the side of those challenging the moral cowardice of the US Congress and the disgraceful collusion of the Westminster Parliament.\n\nLAST December you published my letter lamenting Jon Rahm's decision to accept Saudi Arabian money and join the LIV tour and expressing concern that he was severely compromising his ability to win majors by playing 54-hole \"resort golf\" against inferior competition.\n\nIt gives me no pleasure to say \"told you so\" but his performance at the recent Masters was, to say the least, lacklustre, finishing a distant 45th and never in contention.\n\nGolf is a capricious game, and I would be the first to say that you can't judge a player on a single performance but he looked out of sorts and gave a number of frankly embarrassing interviews seeking to justify his decision and insisting he was ready for the fight.\n\nAs further observation: none of the LIV players really threatened the winner, Scottie Scheffler, and those who started well all fell away on the Sunday, perhaps because they had got too used to playing 54 holes and having the Sunday off.\n\nThe next major up for grabs is the PGA and I would be happy to eat humble pie if Rham or his LIV cohorts make a decent fist of it, but I have my doubts.\n\nIt seems difficult to choose between Mammon or majors, but Jon Rham will not be remembered for the amount of money he made in his career.\n\nKeith Swinley, Ayr.\n\nCould top golfer Jon Rahm be ruing his decision to join up with the LIV tour? "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/john-swinney-to-replace-humza-yousaf-as-scotlands-first-minister/2072809/", "title": "John Swinney to replace Humza Yousaf as Scotland's first minister", "body": "\"My decision to stand for the leadership is not born out of long-held ambition, but rather a profound sense of duty to my party and to my country,\" Swinney, who joined the party as a teenager in 1979, told a cheering audience in Glasgow.\n\n\"I know there's some controversy that I'm the only candidate to stand for the leadership....For me, the fact that I am the only candidate demonstrates that the Scottish National Party is coming back together again now.\"\n\nYousaf, who had become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation when he was sworn in as first minister in 2023, resigned last week after his decision to end a coalition in the Scottish parliament with the Green Party backfired, triggering a race to determine his successor.\n\nShortly after midday on Monday, the deadline for other contenders to join the contest, the SNP confirmed Swinney as its next leader, ending uncertainty around a possible weeks-long process that would have ensued if there were more candidates.\n\nFormer finance minister Kate Forbes, who narrowly lost a leadership contest to Yousaf when Nicola Sturgeon resigned as leader last year, was expected to run but ruled herself out on Thursday.\n\nForbes had said she and Swinney shared a \"common purpose\".\n\nOver the weekend, there were also reports that party activist Graeme McCormick was hoping to challenge Swinney for the leadership, but Sky News reported late on Sunday that he had decided not to proceed with his nomination, citing a statement from him.\n\nThat left Swinney, who was SNP leader from 2000-2004 and had also served as Scotland's deputy first minister and finance minister, as the sole nominee in the contest.\n\nThe SNP has dominated Scottish politics for 17 years but its popularity has slipped over the past year amid a funding scandal, a series of political blunders, and criticism of how it runs the country. It now heads a minority government in Holyrood.\n\nThe slide has boosted the hopes of Britain's opposition Labour Party of regaining ground in Scotland, one of the United Kingdom's four nations, as it seeks to win a British parliamentary election expected later this year.\n\nThe SNP aims to reinvigorate the push for another referendum on independence from the United Kingdom.\n\nScots voted against splitting from the United Kingdom by 55% against 45% in a referendum in 2014, but the independence movement says Britain's later departure from the European Union changed the situation and another referendum is justified - a claim that both the ruling Conservative Party and Labour reject.\n\n(Reporting by Muvija M, Editing by Bernadette Baum and Angus MacSwan)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", This can be achieved next week by:\n\n\"This would free up government time and strategic direction to focus on the many failings in government of the SNP over the past 17 years - which you have played {"uri": "8114022193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:08:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:08:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:08:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/opinion/comment/4971565/kirsty-strickland-john-swinney/", "title": "KIRSTY STRICKLAND: Can John Swinney handle poisoned chalice he inherited?", "body": "John Swinney has become leader of the SNP after nominations closed on Monday without anybody else putting themselves forward for the role.\n\nA coronation then, not a contest.\n\nAfter their recent bout of decidedly-Tory internal chaos, the SNP has decided that what they need now is a period of calm. A leadership contest would have exposed old wounds and given new life to those more recent ones which brought about the downfall of Humza Yousaf.\n\nJohn Swinney's first test as SNP leader will be to secure the backing of parliament in a vote to become First Minister. This is one he is expected to pass, with the support of the Greens.\n\nWhile some within the party will be frustrated that they didn't get a chance to vote on their next leader, many will be relived to see John Swinney at the helm.\n\nHe is a man with extensive experience in the highest levels of government and within the SNP itself. As a former leader of the SNP and a former Deputy First Minister, he will be uniquely placed to hit the ground running.\n\nThe party stalwart won't need an orientation session or a period to settle into his new role. As Nicola Sturgeon's former right-hand man, he already knows the ins and outs of the job. The last week has been a real-time demonstration of his political experience.\n\nHe was deft in his manoeuvres, managing to bring his biggest threat, former leadership challenger Kate Forbes, into the Swinney fold. At the launch of his leadership bid, he spoke a message of unity, promising to work collaboratively to bring the divided party back together again.\n\nHe pledged to give Kate Forbes a high-profile role in his cabinet and she offered him her support.\n\nHe also managed to stave off a move from the grassroots which would have forced a leadership election.\n\nGraeme McCormick had gathered enough signatures for a leadership nomination but decided not to continue with his bid after a ''lengthy and fruitful'' discussion with Swinney. The new SNP leader not only neutralised the threat, he managed to secure McCormick's support too.\n\nThe ability to persuade others is one of the core skills that a politician needs. Over the last decade, it has gone out of fashion.\n\nWe now judge our politicians not on their ability to convince others of their position, but on how vociferously they trash their opponents.\n\nJohn Swinney will need powers of persuasion\n\nAs the leader of a minority government, John Swinney will have to rely on his powers of persuasion to get legislation through. He will have to work in the very way that the Scottish Parliament was set up to encourage. In this, his political opponents may come to regret their success in forcing Humza Yousaf out of office.\n\nThere is no doubt that John Swinney has inherited a poisoned chalice. The problems that Humza Yousaf faced haven't miraculously vanished with him. John Swinney will now be responsible - and accountable for - the pressures on the NHS, falling living standards and the drugs death crisis, to name just a few.\n\nThere is also the small matter of achieving his party's stated aim of independence for Scotland.\n\nBut when it comes down to it, Douglas Ross and Anas Sarwar would much rather be squaring off against Humza Yousaf on those issues than John Swinney.\n\nWhere Humza Yousaf sometimes seemed overwhelmed by the scale of the challenges he inherited from Nicola Sturgeon, John Swinney has been around the block a few times.\n\nHe is much better placed to see beyond the bad headlines, rather than being consumed by them. His critics say he is too close to the old guard of the SNP and, in particular, Nicola Sturgeon, to be able to meaningfully implement real change. Time will tell on that front, but in the short term at least, his opponents might wonder whether it was the smartest move to switch out Humza Yousaf for somebody of John Swinney's experience and ability.\n\nAt the weekend, my boyfriend promised us a gentle walk up an easy hill.\n\nHowever, as we approached the bottom of Ben A'an to begin our stroll, I strongly suspected I had been hoodwinked.\n\nWe were accompanied on the walk by a duo of reluctant ramblers, in the form of my 10-year-old daughter and seven-month old-puppy. Neither seemed particularly enthused by the journey ahead.\n\nMy boyfriend was responsible for stopping the dog from jumping off the rocky terrain and I was responsible for cajoling my daughter up it.\n\nMotivational speeches were offered and eyerolls were given in return. The ascent to the summit was in parts more akin to rock climbing than walking.\n\nMany fellow walkers who saw my daughter and I struggling gave us words of encouragement. It must have been patently obvious that this was not our natural habitat.\n\nFinally, we reached the top and we enjoyed a brief picnic that was only occasionally interrupted by the puppy trying to make a deadly bid for freedom.\n\nA lovely time was eventually had by all, but I will be Googling all my boyfriend's walking route suggestions before agreeing to them in the future.", "source": {"uri": "8112368069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:09:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:09:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:09:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24300251.graeme-mccormick-wants-run-snp-leader/", "title": "Veteran activist explains why he wants to challenge John Swinney for SNP leadership", "body": "Graeme McCormick - a reiterated solicitor who has served as Convener of SNP's Dumbarton branch - was at the All Under One Banner march in Glasgow on Saturday seeking to gather the required support to stand for leader.\n\nIt is understood McCormick believes he is very likely to receive the 100 nominations from at least 20 SNP branches before the Monday deadline.\n\nThe veteran activist has previously been critical of the SNP-led Scottish Government, using last year's party conference to criticise its independence strategy.\n\nREAD MORE: SNP activist seeking to challenge John Swinney for party leadership\n\nMcCormick previously highlighted in an exclusive interview with The National that he felt the route to independence lay in international treaties - a motion for which was rejected at last year's conference, where he also unsuccessfully ran for SNP president.\n\nThe activist still appears to believe this route is the way forward for independence.\n\nIn a letter to The National, McCormick said he wishes to stand because \"I know of no potential candidate who is prepared to call an early Holyrood election\".\n\n\"Central to the campaign is that a majority vote will result in the SNP MPs being instructed to dissolve the union, establish the sovereign government of Scotland, advise the UN that the union is ended and that Scotland will adhere to the terms of the Vienna Convention on the dissolution of a former state,\" he wrote.\n\n\"Under international law, this is the \"how\" of delivering our nation statehood.\"\n\nThe activist also took aim at the \"advent of muscular unionism\" since the Brexit vote in 2016.\n\n\"The powers of the Scottish parliament continue to diminish the longer the SNP is in power,\" he said.\n\n\"We have reached a watershed. Managing devolution is now incompatible with prosecuting independence. As a result, our support is waning.\"\n\nMcCormick added: \"The party must waste no time in debating and resolving this fundamental issue. The leadership contest is the ideal forum.\n\n\"I believe with all my heart and soul that the SNP can deliver a majority vote for an independent Scotland. The polls for Independence are consistently positive. The SNP has the opportunity to regain its lost support if it promises to dissolve the union through the Ballot Box. No other party can do so.\"\n\nIf McCormick secures enough nominations and puts his name forward before a deadline of noon tomorrow then a leadership contest will take place between May 13 - 27 and potentially derail Swinney's ascension as leader and First Minister.\n\nSwinney, meanwhile, argued a divisive SNP leadership contest could delay the party's essential \"rebuild\".\n\nHe told the Sky News programme Sunday Morning with Trevor Phillips: \"I think the SNP has got a chance to start rebuilding from the difficult period that we have had, under my leadership, and bluntly, I'd just like to get on with that as quickly as I possible can do, because every day that we spend in an internal contest, which I think we all probably know the outcome of, we delay the possibility for the SNP to start its rebuilding.\"\n\nSwinney also said his leadership bid had received \"very, very comprehensive support\", including from former finance secretary Kate Forbes, who earlier ruled herself out of the contest.\n\nIf McCormick won the leadership race against Swinney, the activist would not be able to become First Minister as he is not elected in the Scottish Parliament, with the activist reportedly telling members he believes the roles should be run by two different individuals.\n\nMcCormick has been contacted for comment and more details.", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", {"uri": "8110077598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "17:52:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T17:52:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T17:52:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.northern-times.co.uk/news/comment-a-change-in-snp-leader-will-do-nothing-more-than-p-349793/", "title": "COMMENT: 'A change in SNP leader will do nothing more than put icing on a burnt cake'", "body": "Register for free to read more of the latest local news. It's easy and will only take a moment.\n\nA day is a long time in politics. How often have we heard that quip over recent times? If my prematurely greying hair is anything to go by, too often.\n\nI recall what it was like working in the UK Parliament during those rapidly changing Brexit votes in 2019; long days, moving goalposts, and uncertainty for the country. We were told then by many a nationalist that political conduct at Holyrood is different, how badly that has aged.\n\nThe SNP's Maree Todd will feel that. Just hours before Humza Yousaf unceremoniously booted the Scottish Greens from government she was still defending their coalition. A lesson in what happens when your job is to repeat central party lines, not shape them.\n\nJohn Swinney offers Kate Forbes a top government job in bid to become First Minister\n\nKate Forbes will NOT run to be First Minister, instead she backs John Swinney\n\nWhat could John Swinney and Kate Forbes working together mean for the Highlands?\n\nBut on a serious note, all the oxygen in the room is being taken up by the political turmoil in the SNP. People have had enough and want their politicians to focus on the job at hand. That is certainly the feeling I have had shared with me on the doors.\n\nFor too many, access to GPs and dental care is next to impossible. For too many, the opportunity to buy an affordable home in their community is all but gone. For too many, their local school that was once the pride of the community is now left crumbling down.\n\nWe desperately need a government focused on these priorities.\n\nSome may suggest that a new First Minister will do that. That it will be the long awaited day that the government in Edinburgh fixes its broken relationship with rural Scotland. For the interests of our communities, I genuinely wish I shared that hope.\n\nBut a change in SNP leader will do nothing more than put icing on a burnt cake. With 17 years in government, too many in the SNP have for too long chosen to toe the party line and leave rural voices to feel ignored.\n\nThe Highlands has endured - and Liberal Democrats have fought against - the hollowing out of community policing with the centralisation of the police force, the ill judged attempt to impose Highly Protected Marine Areas, endless delays with the dualling of the A9 and now plans to seize control of care services.\n\nThis catalogue of decisions, that run against the interest of our local communities, only points to a centralising diktat in the SNP that runs deeper than one person. I fear this leopard simply cannot change its spots.\n\nThat fear is only reinforced by the SNP's anointed continuity candidate, John Swinney. He is SNP establishment with a history of threatening councils, ring fencing funding and centralising power. He stood shoulder to shoulder with Salmond, Sturgeon and Yousaf and he cannot hide from their shared failures. Is this Back to the Future? It's certainly not a break from the past.\n\nThe Highlands cannot afford more chaos and more of the same.\n\nPeople deserve a real alternative. They deserve their say. We need a change of direction and, across the Highlands, it is the Liberal Democrats that offer it.\n\nDavid Green\n\nScottish Liberal Democrat candidate for Caithness, Sutherland and Ross.", {"uri": "8112324534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "12:28:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T12:28:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:27:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/politics/24300196.real-challenge-snp-will-start-day-general-election/", "title": "Real challenge for the SNP will start the day after General Election", "body": "IT is interesting and rather sad to note that no member of the current Cabinet or even a junior minister felt they have the ability to do the job of First Minister - including the current Deputy First Minister.\n\nThere is only a short amount of time until the Westminster elections. By all opinion polls and recent by-election results, the SNP vote is hovering around the 30% range. In the time we have left it will be very difficult, if not impossible, for any first minister to turn the ship around and avoid the loss of a potentially large number of SNP seats. In the past few years some SNP policies and performance have not been attractive to the average voter.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney: Leadership challenge from SNP activist will 'delay' rebuild\n\nThe real challenge starts the day after the Westminster elections. May 2026 will by that time probably be only 18 short months away. A week is, as the saying goes, a long time in politics. With a good campaign, who knows what the overall result will be?\n\nIt could well be argued that the current lack of a large independence majority in the Scottish Parliament is a direct result of the policy of voting SNP on both ballot papers in May 2021. As a result, more than a million SNP votes on the regional lists ended up being wasted.\n\nA question which must be asked and answered fairly soon is - are we going to repeat the same mistake? Perhaps it is time for personality to be put aside in favour of practicality and for hearts and minds to come together to find a way to maximise the independence vote in May 2026.\n\nI hesitate to quote Winston Churchill, but \"those that fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it.\"\n\nBrian Lawson\n\nPaisley\n\nWITH the General Election at some stage in the future I am left with several questions.\n\nAre the people of Scotland going to change back to pre-1997 voting trends, when the Labour Party ruled the Scottish roost, with Tony Blair and Gordie Broon, who both created and saved us from the financial collapse in 2007?\n\nREAD MORE: Patrick Harvie speaks out after end of Bute House Agreement\n\nOr will the time machine carts us all back further back to 1955 when the Conservatives owned Scottish voters' hearts and minds?\n\nNo! The genie is out of the bottle and, despite the misinformation in some media sources, Scots can see the good and admittedly the bad in our Scottish Government.\n\nThe bad is brought up at every opportunity by most media sources, as we all know that bad news sells. The bad could be reduced but not eliminated by the Scottish Government having the full levers of power, a higher focus on making stuff work better, and not being required to back-fill gaps in the social policy of UK Government. I am not sure if the media noise would reduce much.\n\nThe good could be even better when full fiscal autonomy is achieved, with increased support for the early and later years. I am thinking about care workers and the like, social care in the community, increased dentistry and GP practices.\n\nHowever, on the horizon is a UK General Election which is a fight between Labour and Tory, where the difference is not worth arguing about.\n\nThe Labour Party under Starmer are wedded to sticking to the fiscal austerity that Tories in Westminster have been dishing out like the Dickensian medicine of \"brimstone and treacle\" since 2010, or 14 years.\n\nNo wonder we need them out, but Labour, no change then?\n\nAlistair Ballantyne\n\nAngus\n\nONCE again a week is a long time in politics, especially Scottish politics this week. Over the last week we have seen the fall of the coalition agreement at Holyrood, the resignation of the SNP party leader and First Minister Humza Yousaf, and now we have one candidate forward to be SNP leader and possibly Scotland's new first minister.\n\nIn this candidate, John Swinney MSP, you have experience and commitment, because Mr Swinney has held the second most senior post in government, deputy first minister, along with a number of top-ranked ministerial posts. And it was during Mr Swinney's service in the Cabinet for a number of years that the SNP secured four election victories at Holyrood.\n\nGoing forward, should Mr Swinney secure the position of first minister his experience and service to the Scottish political scene over many years will surely be called upon.\n\nCatriona C Clark\n\nFalkirk\n\nHAVING watched Thursday's FMQs, I cringed as I had to listened to Douglas Ross bumping his gums about how he had single-handedly had removed the FM from post to the rapturous cries and desk-banging from the Tory rabble.\n\nHaving now heard the various SNP announcements about a successor, surely even D Ross must now realise that he \"single handedly\" had managed to remove a FM who, although I had great respect for, was not always universally popular with what can only be described as \"The Dream Team\" so far as reviving SNP fortunes and future electoral success is concerned.\n\nNOW that chattering classes are turning their ire/fire on to John Swinney, we can no longer tell friend from foe. May I offer a word of advice to all backstabbers, saboteurs and agents provocateurs?\n\nWhen the hunting season starts in the US, it is safer to be a bear, as the rednecks are too busy shooting each {"uri": "8113692232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:29:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:29:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:29:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/john-swinney-is-new-snp-leader-but-what-happens-next-13130464", "title": "John Swinney is new SNP leader but what happens next?", "body": "John Swinney is now on track to become Scotland's seventh first minister as early as Tuesday.\n\nJohn Swinney is the new SNP leader and is now on course to succeed Humza Yousaf as first minister of Scotland.\n\nThe former deputy first minister, who served under close ally Nicola Sturgeon, was unopposed in the SNP leadership race following Mr Yousaf's resignation last week.\n\nHaving taken over as SNP leader, Mr Swinney will now need to seek parliamentary approval to succeed Mr Yousaf as first minister.\n\nThe timing is decided by the parliamentary bureau, and could take place as early as Tuesday.\n\nThe parliament will have 28 days to nominate a replacement for Mr Yousaf once his resignation has been accepted by the King.\n\nAs the SNP are by far the largest party in Holyrood, the onus is on them to find a new leader who can work with other parties in a minority government.\n\nThe SNP's tally of 63 MSPs leaves them just short of a majority in the 129-member parliament, meaning politicians from other parties will need to be persuaded to either vote for Mr Swinney, or at least abstain in the ballot, for him to be successful.\n\nThe leaders from other political parties can also put themselves forward and MSPs can nominate a candidate, although it must be seconded by another member.\n\nIf that happens, any candidate that secures more than half of all votes will win the nomination.\n\nIf no one reaches that threshold, the candidate with the fewest votes will be eliminated - with the process repeated until the candidates are whittled down to two.\n\nAt that point, a candidate will only require a simple majority to win.\n\nRead more:\n\nWho is John Swinney?\n\nWhoever wins the vote is then formally appointed by the King.\n\nAn official swearing-in ceremony at the Court of Session in Edinburgh will then take place.\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Listen above then tap here to follow the Sky News Daily wherever you get your podcasts \ud83d\udc48\n\nHowever, if no new first {"uri": "8109804126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "14:21:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T14:21:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T14:20:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/viewpoint/24298033.swinney-wanted-election-tory-leader-change-call-one/", "title": "Neil Mackay: Swinney wanted election with Tory leader change. He should call one.", "body": "This article appears as part of the Unspun: Scottish Politics newsletter.\n\nBreathe deep. Can you smell the Scottish exceptionalism in the air? It's quite something.\n\nIt seems that unless the nation is subjected to the spectacle of another - this time last-minute - outbreak of factionalism within the SNP, John Swinney will receive his coronation as First Minister.\n\nThe SNP hate the word 'coronation', incidentally. For the nationalist base, it really gets under their skin.\n\nUnderstandably so. Every time the Tories dump a leader and crown a new one without seeking a fresh mandate from voters, the SNP screams for a general election. And they're quite right in their oft-repeated demands.\n\nYet, strangely, they never seem to fancy an election when it's they who are crowning their own Top Cat, as they've done for a second time in a row now that Swinney's moment has come.\n\nHere, for example, is Nicola Sturgeon in October 2022, back when she was First Minister herself, commenting on what should happen after the vertiginous fall of Liz Truss: \"Of course there should be general election.\n\n\"The governance of any country cannot simply be a revolving door that one party gets to pick time and time again who occupies the highest office in the land. It's preposterous, democratically.\"\n\nThe Tories, she said, \"can't keep changing who occupies Number 10 without getting democratic legitimacy... Do I think that is going to happen? That the Tories are voluntarily going to concede that? No.\"\n\nUnspun | Neil Mackay: Yousaf and the SNP deserve to fall, and Scotland deserves an election\n\nHmm. The then Westminster leader Ian Blackford also called for a general election, as did a certain John Swinney.\n\nAt the time, Conservative Party chairman Craig Hoy cravenly insisted the party should serve out its full five-year term.\n\nSwinney, then Sturgeon's deputy, called on the Conservatives to \"do the decent thing\". He added: \"We should have a general election and I don't think the Conservative Party should be allowed to play any more of their games... The people of this country must be given the chance to decide on the way we are governed moving forward.\"\n\nOne again: hmm. This is so confusing, isn't it? As the SNP insist there's absolutely no need for an election now Swinney is in the chair. The excuse - obviously - is that the Scottish Parliament votes in the First Minister, not the ruling party.\n\nYes, well, that's all very 'angels dancing on pinheads' really in terms of its merit as an argument. There's no question of Swinney not getting voted in by the parliament thanks to the numbers commanded by the SNP, the Greens and the lonely Alba representative. The smokescreen is rather thin, to be honest.\n\nUnspun | Neil Mackay: Yes movement is not prepared for crushing blow lying ahead\n\nYet surely there's more to this than just sticking to parliamentary bureaucracy? Isn't there such a thing called 'honour'? What's good for the goose is good for the gander, right? If the SNP wanted to they could trigger an election to give Swinney a valid mandate.\n\nUnder the Scotland Act, it just takes a two-thirds majority of MSPs to vote for an election and it happens. I'm sure the opposition parties would oblige in making up the numbers.\n\nNot that the opposition parties have anywhere to hide either. Labour in Wales just installed a new First Minister with no election, and as we know Rishi Sunak, like Liz Truss, took power with no recourse to the electorate.\n\nBoth Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss took the reins of power without a general election mandate\n\nAll these parties can, of course, hide behind parliamentary rules and structures to stop the people having a say when they change the heads of our governments, but it looks thoroughly dishonourable, cowardly, manipulative and hypocritical.\n\nIt will be interesting to see what the SNP's position should be in the very near future if the Tories turn on Sunak and inflict another new leader on Britain without an election.\n\nIt's entirely likely, after all. The knives are already being sharpened for the Prime Minister after the Tory Party's dismal performance in England's local elections and at the Blackpool by-election.\n\nOf course, the SNP would simply fall back on the line that its Holyrood which elects the First Minister, not the ruling party as in Westminster. But that's such a transparent fig leaf, it feels almost inappropriate.\n\nSwinney is now running an administration for which Sturgeon won a mandate. After she scarpered, we had Humza Yousaf. The deal with the Greens is done. Yet we are supposed to accept that nothing has changed substantively to demand a fresh mandate. It just doesn't wash. In truth, it's thoroughly anti-democratic.\n\nNobody is demanding perfection from politicians - just a little consistency and integrity. Trust in democracy is at rock bottom. If we want strong political systems we need to have politicians not just held to account, but willing - eager, in fact - to have their mandates tested and affirmed at every opportunity which demands it by the electorate.", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
